column7: ASTROMUNDUS - Astrophysics
column88: The programme should employ at least one person at each partner university who's ONLY task is to coordinate, organise and facilitate the integration of students. We had very little time to integrate because a feature of each programme is that the courses are overloaded with mostly useless content! So, the student is kept busy and unable to integrate or try solve problems that might crop up in their daily lives. There was only ONE secretary employed at the University of Innsbruck who worked PART-TIME!!! Her job was supposed to assist with visa and other bureaucratic questions, update our exam results in the student portal and answer questions that might pertain to other consortium partners! The so-called "academic advisors" in Rome and Göttingen were academics whom also teach, supervise and do research in each department. The result is that they, themselves, aren't much invested in assisting international students (particularly in Rome!). They are not well-informed either; they don't have the time for it. AstroMundus seems to be run by a group of people who all want the programme to work, but none of them are willing to invest the time, human and material resources in order for the programme to run smoothly! Students end up having a lot of problems that have little to do with the content of the programme, but more so with the lack of design and implementation of the programme.
column101: I have no idea. They would probably first attempt talking to a lecturer, who may or may not have something to do with the programme, or attempt to come into contact with the local "academic advisor". The student representative for my programme, 2011-2013, was very poorly  chosen and not an option.
column103: I have yet to see that any of the consortium partners are open to criticism! These people only want praise.
column104: ANONYMOUS ONLINE FEEDBACK such as this survey! We were expected to fill out paper-based questionnaires which were then supposed to be handed in PERSONALLY.
column117: Whether the programme's existence is at all justified and whether the European taxpayers' money couldn't be spent on more pressing issues other than this programme.
column118: - time spent on thesis preparation - less emphasis on memory-based learning and testing - courses that are not overloaded with useless information that is either not examined and neither applicable nor referred back to at any later stage in the programme
column119: I suggest that the European Commission discontinue funding for this programme.

column104: Groningen was very responsive to students, no change required. RWTH Aachen makes no effort to act upon student feedback. The local program requires substantial changes.
column118: (1) The 2nd year at RWTH Aachen does not include practical experience. Their idea of practicals is a lab tour. (2) The administration for the BME program at RWTH Aachen is completely disorganized. It is next to impossible to get a clear answer on any matter. (3) The program at RWTH Aachen is said to offer 3 different specializations. This is completely false. All 2nd year students take the same courses despite their specialization. The most grievous offense is that the specialization for tissue engineering has only 1 related course.
column119: The University of Groningen is fantastic. All involved at that university should be applauded. The professors see to the needs of their students and are willing to tailor the program to the background of each, so everyone can spend their time learning something new. RWTH Aachen on the other hand assumes students arrive with a blank slate and treat them as such. Students end up taking redundant courses between the first and second years as RWTH Aachen is unwilling to accept those prior courses.  RWTH Aachen should be removed from the program.

One more problem is that there are only few courses that are taught in English in TU Berlin, most of them are in German language, even many recommended courses from the COSSE course list in TU BErlin was in German. column88: Integration at Polytechnique has been impossible. Nobody in Graduate School knew much about us Erasmus Mundus students so to provide us information about the modules, courses etc., the students organization has appearently NO interest in involving non-French students in the activities and foreign students are often living in different buildings, so that interaction with Polytechnicians is null. It feels like being a pariah in a world of cool people wearing fancy uniforms and carrying swords.  The situation is radically different in Warwick, I don't think much else needs to be done: the Freshers' Week and the Student Societies Fair is enough to start networking with the local students, and on an academic level the Complexity department is a big and perfecly organized family, enrolling to courses in other departments is easy and the access to information is immediate.
column101: Contacting the administration in Warwick is easy and a prompt response is guaranteed in most of the cases. They are attentive to our questions and problems, so that one has no problem in discussing formally or unformally any matter.
column103: Much work has to be done regarding the French node, especially as in having the EMM students properly recognized by the Polytechnique itself and finding an adequate set of modules for them within the school. It seems that new students are already experiencing less discomfort in this than previous years' students, and this is all I can base my opinion on right now.
column104: It would be great if Warwick could control more deeply and accurately the modules proposed by the other universities and ask directly for some sort of feedback on them rather than having this whole thing passing thru Paris, where one single person is in charge of everything, and sometimes it results a bit hard to discuss with. Direct contact with Warwick would help indeed.
column118: *integration in Polytechnique (both on a "human" and an academic point of view)  *the extremely slow communication in Polytechnique - not to mention a certain "aggressivity" from the responsibles sometimes.  *I wish students could be granted a bus pass in Paris, which costs more than 1 scholarship of EU students - things are better for non-EU, but still...
column119: Ehm, I'm not sure what else I should write here. About the french bus pass thing: it's a nightmare staying in Polytechnique without one, and it's too expensive for EU students given the reduced scholarship. Half of it should be paid by the people where we do the M1 or M2 project, but we'd need a pass well before that time...It would be nice if EU and non-EU students were taxed of the same proportion in order to fund a bus pass for everyone staying at Polytechnique.  OH! ONE MORE THING! It's terrible the feeling of "being in prison", such that it's forbidden to anyone to leave Polytechnique for a brief period if not after filling thousands of forms, declarations etc. ... I understand that we're paid to stay there and do things, but still..!

column88: 1. More information about living expenses would have been very valuable prior to the beginning of my period at each university (for example a compilation of basic products prices in supermarkets, transportation options and most important BANK options and accommodation options)  2. More information about registration procedures would be appreciated (Uni 1, Uni 2 were good in providing them).  3. More information about the structure of the university and how is our master placed in the administrative apparatus, as well as a how-to guide of how to get by through the complicated bureaucracy.
column101: The student would have to address an issue hierarchically in this order: teacher in charge of the course, local tutor, local coordinator (or local secretary), consortium secretary, consortium coordinator.  Alternatively, for really tense situations, the students have sent an official letter to all the people involved in the consortium, to voice their concerns.
column103: This is really an unfair question, because it's not a Yes / No one. I would say they have corrected some of the shortcomings we've signaled, but definitely not all of them. And while some of our complaints are not so easy to address, there are some which shouldn't be so complicated, but nothing has been done about. However, overall the consortium was decently reactive.
column104: 1. They have an internet portal for access to course resources which also has a feedback module implemented: USE IT!  2. REALLY LISTEN to what is not going well! Students are not there to complain, but to be sure they are having the best working conditions (which is what a European Master should offer).  3. DO NOT treat students with superiority! Some of us are professionals who gave up on jobs to start a master program to improve our skills. No matter our background we deserve to be taken seriously and NOT BE TREATED LIKE PERPETUALLY UNSATISFIED CHILDREN.
column117: First, this alumni association should start doing their job well. They are virtually in-existent and in the case of my Erasmus experience, I've crossed them only a couple of times for pointless meetings.  There are several important issues they should address, especially since they are alumni and they've gone through these situations already: 1. housing (decent accommodation for someone traveling to a completely foreign countries) 2. setting up channels for informing people about living expenses 3. setting up channels for informing people about administrative procedures needed for immigration purposes, social purposes (sometimes social help is available, but students cannot know about it, whereas alumni do), uni administration purposes  ALL these are important!
column118: 1. Housing. It is ridiculous to expect a student moving half-way around the continent or the world to know everything about housing availability, real estate market and so on. Moreover, a student cannot decide for a place (especially rent an apartment w/o seeing it first). Get something done about accommodation, because it's making us lose a lot of time and a lot of the (little) money some of us have. Additionally it transforms the whole moving into a foreign country experience in a living hell. Just be more informative to people!  2. Finances! Do something about the scholarships for the EU students! They are ridiculous and cannot motivate them, especially when you compare them to the non-EU students. When you go in a store to buy a bread, nobody asks you whether you're from Antigua just to charge you twice for the bread - so why do they receive 2 times more the scholarship, EU students receive. Not only it's not fair, but the thing which is the most disturbing is that the amount an EU student receives barely helps him get by! I challenge anyone from EACEA to try and pay rent + utilities + food + transportation with a bit more than 400 EUR / month.  3. Find a way to evaluate teachers! Some of them shouldn't be teaching in international programs. Evaluate their English speaking skills (if us, as students are required to get a certificate of English as a foreign language, teachers should do to, because some of them don't manage to make themselves understood). Then, evaluate the grades their students get; sometimes problems can be tracked from this kind of investigation. Then, ask for feedback from the students and actually take it into account.
column119: 1. For most of the problems regarding moving in a foreign countries, each master course HAS TO be required to have a web page referencing this kind of information in whichever form they wish (a wiki would be perfect and easy to build with the help of graduate students).  2. Insist on a better dialogue between students and teachers, based on reciprocal respect and professionalism, not a parent-child type of dialogue.

column7: DMKM - Data Mining & Knowledge Management
column15: TECHNICAL UNIVERSITY OF CATALONIA Ð BARCELONA TECH
column88: There were no syllabi provided for any of the courses until after I had already accepted the program, and even then not for some time.  The bank/university took a month after being here before giving us any money. There are classes 10h00 to 17h00 every day, so there's no time for sports or anything like that (which is okay, except that a few of the classes are not helpful).
column101: I have no idea.
column103: I'm not sure, as we ourselves have not yet given recommendations.
column104: Make it known that they exist.
column118: 1)  The program does an awful job of describing the courses in advance. Unless you talk with a current or former student, there's no way to find out any specifics of the courses or their prerequisites (no syllabi on the website, etc.). 2)  Related to the first point, the program accepts many (in fact, mostly) students without the appropriate backgrounds for the courses. I do well because I just finished university and have a strong enough background in math and computer science. Some of the students, however, have come into the program not knowing how to code (and some of the classes require extensive programming) and not having had some basic math background (with some classes containing reasonably difficult mathematical concepts). Some students have the background, but haven't seen it in 10 years. This inhibits the ability of the professors to provide the best content and also means that the students without the proper background have to work incredibly hard to catch up, and they wind up depressed and discouraged. This is all do to the fact that prerequisites are not communicated in advance and that the program accepts unqualified candidates. 3)  In the first semester of the program, all students take the same courses in order to provide "the same background material required for the rest of the course." However, it seems there's some requirement to include a professor from each university, because, despite extensive complaints, they continue to offer a software methodologies class from the university in Bucharest that teaches almost exclusively outdated concepts, and with a professor who does nothing but read text off of slides for 3 hours at a time.  Each year complains, but they do nothing to change. The logic class is okay, but is not at all required for all specialties (which students branch off into after the first semester). In order to improve, the program should either eliminate the common courses the first semester and jump straight into specialties, or do a better job of determining what is truly relevant for the whole masters.

Some professors don't even speak proper english (once we spend half an hour to explain a simple question to a professor and ended just giving up). Some lessons are of very good qualities, but the difference is big. We have come to the point of completely disregarding some lessons and using that time to do our coursework.  3. This master is described on the internet as master to "Training high-skilled engineers and researchers in DMKM to fit both industry and academic research needs." I quote this from http://www.em-dmkm.eu/Description/38-EN-Objectives. Nonetheless this is misleading, since once I got here I noticed several professors have the idea that they are training researchers. Consequently, some contents taught are out of sync with the  types of contents, tools and techniques that are required in the industry. I've heard that it is consequently hard to find a job for those of us who don't want to work as researchers after graduating. It is misleading to offer this as a master training engineers to fit industry requirements.

column88: I was surprised by the fact that Course coordinator Ms.Delphine had problems with English in terms of understanding.  I personally faced a backlash because of it. As soon as I got the admission letter for the EM-DMKM Masters, I quit my job. I was waiting for the scholarship updates from Ms.Delphine, as my name was in reserve list. Meanwhile I was exploring my funding options. One month later I was disappointed to hear from Ms.Delphine that I cannot participate into this programme. But I have never withdrawn my application at any point of time. I have been trying hard for this since 2010. So I requested Mr.Zighed to look into this matter. Finally I was admitted into the program as a self funded student. My scholarship opportunity was denied because of a mistake that was commited by Ms.Delphine.  I still have some pending issues which is still unresolved. Just to let you know that I arrived in Lyon on September 3, 2011(saturday afteroon) and stayed until September 8,2011.  ie.,I vacated on 8th morning. So apparently my stay for these 5 nights should have costed 175. But 210 have been deducted from my account, as Ms.Delphine had the authorization of our bank accounts. She promised to resolve this issue. But it remains to be pending until now and I have not recieved my 35 back.  Also felt that the consortium was not transparent or bothered to listen to students problem.

But machine learning should be a core topic of DMKM master!!. I have to prise Barcelonatech, though. Their courses had very useful content & homeworks.    2) Students selection - I found few people really interested in data mining 3) There was no "Big data" mandatory course, a topic which is all the rage these days in data mining, they should definitely add it to the curricula.

column118: Language Course Material Organization
column119: Language was a serious problem with this Master Program. We were asked to provide proof English language proficiency but apparently the same was not required from the professors of the courses and other teaching staff like teaching assistants. Many of the professors and staff had serious problems communicating and explaining the topics they were discussing during class in Engish.   The program was completely ill-organized. The coordinators failed to respond to emails. The courses were not well organized - specially the ones conducted over video-conferencing. The connections broke and half of the time of the lectures were lost fixing technical issues related to this. This, coupled with poor communication skills of the professors led to a very poor overall experience.   The course material was also generally below par. Many courses repeated content and there was no coordination between professors and universities to avoid this. I strongly believe that this master could have been finished in 2 semesters instead of 3 if all the repetitions were eliminated. Also, the course content was not of very high standard. Many topics which are considered to be essential in this field were not touched.  Course grading was also completely bogus for many courses. Many professors failed to give ANY feedback for assignments and exams. The overall grading system was also not good. It was pre-decided that none of the students would fail the courses and retakes were a complete joke. The students who took the retakes ended up scoring better than other students. I believe that this has serious repercussions for the students as well as the master program itself.

column7: EMDC - European Master in Distributed Computing
column88: Would have been nice if we'd been introduced to the research activities within the different groups at the institutes, so that those of us who're interested in PhD careers could have followed through, developed an idea of what thesis topics we'd be interested in, or conduct independent research with these groups.
column101: Email/Discuss with Johan Montelius, the programme coordinator.
column103: I don't know if my suggestions have been incorporated for the junior batches.
column104: The main problem is that there seems to be little or no communication between IST and KTH regarding administrative and course related matters. The programme coordinator who is very approachable (Johan Montelius) is with KTH, and the feedback we give him does not seem to reach IST in any way.
column117: The consortium needs to handle student theses together. In our case, KTH and UPC were flexible with regards to where their students could pursue their thesis projects (be it within one of the university's research groups or with the industry). IST on the other hand was not, and this would only affect those of us who were to do our theses at IST. In the end, it was a very rough process for me to end up doing my Master thesis in Berlin after being assigned at IST.
column118: More communication between IST and KTH on all matters,  1) administrative matters (IST has still not transferred my thesis grades transferred to KTH, preventing KTH from issuing me a degree). Fortunately, a provisional certificate was all that was needed for my current job, but this is unacceptable in any case.  2) Unify the thesis assignment procedure: give students the flexibility to pick thesis advisors from any university in the consortium, and allow those of us who are interested to do thesis projects from external labs and the industry. Currently, the way a student is hard-assigned to a university for the thesis semester makes this impossible.  3) The coursework at IST and KTH was excellent and top-notch, and the skills I picked up have given me an edge in my current job. Nevertheless, it would be great if we had the opportunity and time (which we didn't have) to conduct independent research during the masters programme so as to benefit those of us who're interested in PhD careers (akin to how master students help with research in the US system).
column119: Same as above, with regards to providing us with time to conduct independent research with professors in order to publish a paper or two by the time we graduate, which would help us greatly in case we're pursuing a PhD afterwards.  Also, the summer break between the 2nd semester of the course at IST and the 3rd semester of the course at KTH is too short (little more than a month), which makes it impossible to do an internship.

column7: EMGS - Global Studies - A European Perspective
column101: Every two months, there is a student representatives meeting with the University coordinators.  Also, during Winter School (held in the end of the first semester) and Summer School (held in the end of the fourth semester), students representatives from each university will discuss with the Consortium on comments/feedback regarding to the program.  Thus, a student can bring up their concern to their student representatives, who will then highlight their case to the coordinators or Consortium during such sessions.  Alternatively, the student can contact their coordinator directly - if the case is highly personal or sensitive and the student do not want to share with a fellow student.
column103: In Winter School, student representatives from each university will provide their feedback/comments to the Consortium - who will then take it up or provide clarification on why certain rules or process are in place.  Also, students will be informed of recommendations that will be implemented in future during Summer School or email.
column104: I believe the Consortium & their coordinators have done an excellent job in ensuring many channels of communication that students could use to reach out to the Consortium

column119: Most of the students in the program were fresh from their undergraduate year.  It will be more beneficial for the student's learning experience if there is a right balance of students with few years of work experience and those with none.   Most of the student jobs available are for those who knows the native tongue.  Thus, students like me who are not fluent in the native tongue will not be able to apply and get students jobs.  It will be nice if there are student job opportunities for international students , who speak fluently in the medium of instruction of the course (which in my case was English)

column88: There is much room for improvement with regards to the support that Roskilde University can provide in terms of navigating the Visa process and registration with the Danish authorities. I eventually had to get three separate visa's each requiring a new and separate application, this was not only VERY time consuming but also very costly. Despite being a Erasmus Mundus Scholarship holder I experienced the Danish bureaucracy and certain administrative staff at Roskilde University to be somewhat xenophobic. I was highly disappointed with the lack of support or understanding from the parties involved.   This experience was however completely the opposite with my studies in Leipzig. I arrived slightly later than the other students and was quickly integrated into the programme and was provided with immense support in terms of navigating the visa process as well as the other administrative tasks that were required for me to commence my studies.
column101: There exist a number of mechanisms. Firstly the respective university coordinators could be approached. The response time and willingness to engage with students varies between the Universities. Leipzig and Vienna, I know for sure, are very willing and able to help in whichever way they can. Roskilde is somewhat less enthusiastic about providing assistance. I do not have experience of the situation at the LSE or at Wroclaw.  The student representatives act as the link between the student body and the consortium. This is unfortunately highly dependent on the cohesion of the student body themselves.
column104: Not much more can be done than is already being implemented without becoming somewhat patronizing. The students are also responsible for taking up any issues through the appropriate channels. In some cases this requires more initiative than others. This is nonetheless part of growing up and assuming responsibility.
column118: 1.) Navigation of the bureaucracy.  2.) Provision of a single permit for the duration of studies.
column119: Some students were provided with a 2 year residents permit while others had to re-apply after the first year. Given the structure of the curriculum and mobility track this poses a number of problems, especially for Non-EU students.

In terms of courses, UCSB limited Erasmus students in the choice of subjects. In the University of Wroclaw the main gap was the lack of resources in English, luckily I speak Polish and it wasn't a problem for me, however, for other students it can be a bit problematic. column16: UNIVERSITY OF AIX-MARSEILLE III PAUL CÉZANNE
column88: At the Universita di Bologna there was no real welcoming session. They were mainly concerned with the attendance of students, but there was no social gathering or academic talks organised. The University should focus more on providing an academic discussion rather than treating postgraduate students like first year freshers.   The EUR and AMU organised a welcome gathering and introduced us to all other students and PhD candidates. There was a very warm welcome by those two Universities!
column101: There are three ways:  1. Student Representative: At each term there is an election of a student representative. One could notify the representative who would then bring up the matter at the midterm meeting.  2. Ombudsman: One could contact the Ombudsman.  3. University of Hamburg: Administrative issues like allocations are handled by the University of Hamburg. One can always contact the coordinators at Hamburg directly.
column103: Yes! At the first term students complained about the teaching of Public Law and Economics. After we complained at the evaluation forms, the teacher was replaced.
column104: After I have completed this postgraduate course and also an undergraduate course with a University consortium, I have several improvements in mind. However, I do not have the time to participate in all meetings. Thus, it might be a good idea to introduce a way for Alumni students to send in ideas and recommendations in writing.
column117: It is necessary to find a way to evaluate the dedication of the different universities. I had the feeling that some universities are more dedicated to the programme than others.
column118: Dedication of Universities: Some universities are more dedicated than others. The experience of the programme depends mainly on the dedication of the Universities. Universities like the EUR, Hamburg, Ghent are very dedicated and organise academic talks and debates, whereas the Universita di Bologna was only concerned with attendance, but did not organise any talks.  Truly Interdisciplinary Programme: In the programme there are either economics faculties or Law Schools involved. This resulted in a few errors in law during the analysis. Whereas the professors at EUR are jurists with additional degrees in economics, at other universities there are only economists. I find it necessary to divide the teaching between the faculty of economics and law at each university.   Comparative Law: The analysis of law was mainly focused on American Law, because most academics publishing in L&E are American scholars. However, the American approaches are very problematic in Europe, as they infringe the constitutional provisions in EU Member States / EU Charta on human Rights. I would advice an analysis focusing on the Law of EU Member States in an comparative analysis with the American approach/law.
column119: Unfortunately, the Course European Union Law and Economics is only offered at the University of Hamburg (Third Term). I find it necessary to teach the course at all Universities, as the EMLE programme is intended to provide for European Integration.  Also I would suggest to provide more specialisation. Instead of offering Public Law and Economics, Comparative Law and Economics, etc. I suggest to offer two/three main (large) modules Comparative Law and Economics I and II in term I and II. The two modules should cover the main ideas in Constitutional/Public, Criminal and Contract Law. Further modules like Competition Law and Economics, Intellectual Property Law and Economics, Labour Law and Economics, etc should be offered as optional modules taught in smaller, intense seminars. It should be possible to visit all seminars, but it is only necessary to sit the Comparative L&E, an economics module and two optional modules each term.  Furthermore, I would suggest to include more economic modules. So far it is compulsory to sit Microeconomics in the first term. I would also include Macroeconomics and Industrial Economics (or similar modules) in the second and third term.  The EMLE provides a great environment for specialisation and the study of different theories and ideas. I think this course provides the best possible potential for a truly interdisciplinary programme with specialisation in different areas of L&E.

column118: 1. The thesis process was a shambles 2. Exams were not returned to students 3. Limited types of assessment methods
column119: 1. The assessment of my thesis did not meet the rules/requirements circulated by faculty yet there was no way to have it reviewed. My thesis (and many others) was scored with a divergence of over 40% suggesting that some supervisors do not understand what they are preparing students for. My external reviewer made factually incorrect statements but there was no process to address these. None of these concerns were responded to in a timely manner (i.e. it took months and several emails to get a response) and the response failed to engage with any of the issues raised. 2. How are students expected to learn if they are not provided with their marked exams in order to see what they did right/wrong. The failure to return exams also poses serious transparency issues for the assessment. 3. In Bologna the only form of assessment was examination. It is unclear that this is the most effective didactic tool at your disposal.

column88: It was certainly interesting to meet co-students from so many different countries and studying in three different places. You learn to be flexible and adjust in new situations. Nevertheless I am not convinced that this programm leads be perform academically well. IT is a programm for those who want to experience Europe. A certain peer group pressure is created by the group as well with insiders and outsiders. The accomodation in Bologna was very bad, and the library is inadequate to learn and discuss as groups. Travelling and Partying played an important and vital role. But I don't think that this has enhanced my social abilities. I think for people with less money especially from poorer countries or no scholarship it is hard to keep up with the social gatherings.

column88: The library tour should be given in the first week and not so many weeks after classes have started. Theperson responsible for the administration is hardly in office and apperantly filling in 2 small papers, requires her to let you wait for 4 days. While when arriving at her office she is laughing and not doing anything for work. Furthermore, no tour around the city is provided. Professors are chaotic and during lectures go all the time of track of the materials at hand. Furthermore, registering separate at each university is inefficient. If we are registered for the master it must have been done for us.
column101: Address the professor in class. However, this is always so chaotic that nobody does it.
column104: The website for our courses made by google needs easier access and a discussion board.
column117: The quality and organization of the master. Which includes the content. The master is described to be of high quality why academicly it is very weak. Wrong information stated on lecture slides, chaotic structure of courses, professor does not stay on topic during lectures. Conclusion, the master has some serious errors and I feel ashamed that this program is sponsored by the European Union. Apperantely, even during the current economical crisis Europe is not taking quality as an assessment criteria for financial support. And above all, most scholarships are given to non-Europeans. The argument for this could be to attract intellectual people. But having seen the people in  class I can only conclude that the European Union is sponsoring parties and tourists from outside the EU.
column118: Course content Course structure Academic staff, they should keep to the topic
column119: I feel ashamed to have joined this master. Having previously studied at another European university, I can say with the utmost confidence that this master is academicly the worst of his kind. And above all I am frustrated that it gets the Erasmus Mundus quality lable. It was this lable which should ensure quality. However, failure on the side of the people who judged the program is more than proven. And I can only hope that when this master is again assessed that it will be done seriously. Check the actual content and don't only assess whether the lay out looks good but really go into the content, structure and professors.

column101: Communicate with the program manager who is not actually the person in leadership. The manager then communicates with the party involved. Students communication is through the manager only in internal hierarchy that exists in the channels of communication in the program.
column103: Students in my experience are not seen as partners in the process therefore suggestions that could benefit the consortium and the masters program as an educational program are hardly ever taken into consideration.
column104: Consortium members, that is the leading staff have to be more open and available for student feedback and to follow up on the recommendations. Students, as graduate students, have to be seen partners in the educational process, that is the main reason a program like this exists. Egos and the feeling of superiority must be set aside for effective communication and successful collegial relationships between students and professors.
column118: If this program desires to prepare leaders in migration, there are some fundamental alterations necessary. There need to be a shift in professors unprepared to prepare such leaders. There need to be higher education training offered to instructors who have not had an education on pedagogy and assessment. Given the nature of this program (intercultural relations), the dimension of cultural respect for diversity that comes with students intellectual backgrounds and trajectories should be respected and attended to especially given the "rigorous" student selection that takes place before any cohort is conformed. The program, as an educational endeavor, is bound to fail without any fundamental changes, and its promise to opening up educational possibilities in my experience is already a failure.
column119: *The program is a wonderful idea, with a provocative invitation to learn but with insufficient intellectual resources to execute it. The program should not admit students with a trajectory and an academic background that cannot supported in the course of the program. Else, include more prepared instructors to teach the main courses. This may mean releasing some of the main the leaders of each of the partner institutions from the teaching duties for which they are not well prepared. Some of the visiting scholars, leaders in their field, thoughtful and well prepared is an option. *Student assessment is disrespectful intellectually given the very poor content and instruction of some of the courses. Appeals in the grading process is not respected according to the guidelines. Deadlines are not respected in this process. Additionally, the assessment guidelines are vague, to say the least, leading to any dispute being irrelevant, and to claims being unsustainable from any perspective. Allegiances amongst the professors and partner institutions make the grading and appeal process unfair and not based on academic and intellectual potential.

column118: 1) Helping coordinating logistics before arrival: before students arrive to a country, they have zero knowledge about the city and its prices. Helping students to understand what to expect is critical to helping them to set themselves up for success. This responsibility can be dished off to other students at the university to save admin-time.  2) Helping to build a social network immediately upon arrival: setting up "mechanisms" (e.g., groups, organizations, parties, etc.) in which students interact and socialize upon arrival.  3) Provide basics for students to help themselves upon arrival. For example, making sure students have internet at student dorms right away, will let them solve their own problems. Without internet (and often without phones) in the first few days, it is very hard to figure out what to do to help yourself right away

column88: When I arrived to ULG they made a very big effort to provide accomodation. And after a couple of days they found a very good accomodation for me. It was not easy but they made a great job, because at that time I didn't speak french. In the personal and professional ULG made an execellent job, my best experience as Erasmus mundus student.  Then in the ECN we already have an accomodation from day 1 until the last day. It was a very nice accomodation, and they introduce all the students associations and the international office. I have to say that the ULG french course was more professional than ECN, maybe because at the ULG they have an internet platform to improve at home.  Finally at the UNIGE nobody really care about us. The housing support was useless and there was no compromise at all. I spend two months in the summer to find an accomodation. Nobody provides any information for the language courses. The visa/residence permit was really difficult to complete and there was a lack of information in all the process. They never present an estimation of living expenses. The local transportation was very bad there was a lot of strykes and delates. I lost two important meetings because of the strykes. There was no fieldwork. Very disorganized. We arrive to Italy in summer nobody answer a phone. Very inadequate
column101: I think these surveys are the formal way. Because when we tray to speak with the professor there is no confidentiality and it becomes very difficult to speak with clarity.  But the problem is the time required to fix the problems is too much. Because the problems already pass and after the next generations some changes could be done.

column118: My internship is very important because when I finished my master I need an experience for a job. But there was no internship. They say my thesis was the internship, but it's not true. So at the end when I finally got the information to develop my thesis it was too late, I had like two months to finish the thesis.  Finally, the contact with international companies; I see a lot of European companies but too little companies that looks for people worldwide. Because, if you are not European, it becomes really complicate to got a working visa.

EMTM - European Master in Tourism Management
column88: The EMTM course has been very new in the generation of 2010 and full of mistakes and insufficient organization. In numerous cases my time and budget have suffered due to misinformation or no information. For example, visa issuing in Slovenia - I have advised I will be in and out of the country on monthly basis and have received a confirmation that in that case visa is not necessary. However, upon the arrival, I was told i needed a visa and had to stay at the opposite side of the town for months, which caused longer travels, gas expenses, not being able to participate in group projects and higher rent. My visa procedure had some delays at the embassy and it took the university three months to finally listen to my request and get involved. Eventually, I got the visa for the final two weeks of the entire 4-month semester.  Another example is misguidance by the coordinator Justyna K. which made the entire class believe she will asssist in arranging summer internships. the arrangements and a conference call with her took place during two final weeks of the semester after which she simply stopped anwering to anyone who applied. Everyone was supposed to propose three companies and she could not accommodate any of them. This was again a very unprofessional move because after I have contacted the companies myself they have offered to work for them. Due to late arrangements and all delays, my summer work took longer and i could return only a week later then the official begining of the classes. The courses and projects started already and my final grade suffered due to this. These are only two example of completely wrong guidence, misinformation and negligence caused by coordinators Yustina from Girona and Jozica in Slovenia. The coordinator for danish university we have never even met or knew there is one until she showed up at the end of the semester (she was stationed in a different city). I have paid 14000 E only for the course and you can only imagine my disappointment.
column101: According to my experience, approaching the ex coordinator (Yustina K.) does not function because she was working with all the professors in the consortium. When I asked to receive a contact of a person that is above the consortium, she constantly refused to provide one.
column103: I have addressed several concerns however the program itself is one closed network and the comments that I had have gone directly against the program coordinating, thus have been ignored.
column104: Provide contacts of persons in charge of monitoring the validity of the program. Introduce outside perssonel.
column117: Accessibility
column118: Administration, monitoring of the course coordination, validity of information provided

My overall experience is, that every university had its own rules/guidelines to be followed (in terms of grading-systems, how to write an assignment etc.), at this was a big issue to many of us - it was very confusing to understand new structures at each university.
column119: The main issue to be improved, is closely linked to the above questions. During the last semester (dedicated to master thesis), we were all very confused about the rules depending on which university the supervisor came from (Denmark, Ljubljana or Girona). Example; at one university, the thesis was to be hand in as a book with goldenletters on the frontpage, at one university we had to hand in three copies of the thesis, while on another university no one had to print and hand-in a hard copy. This is just an example - it got us all very confused, so I would highly recommend that a unified thesis-guidelines/handbook is developed (make it the same for all universities), so each student have to follow the same rules and guidelines.

column7: EMTM - European Master in Tourism Management
column88: I was overall very satisfied by the efforts of all universities to integrate us. The only change I would suggest would be to get introduced to more local students, maybe through the organizing of a common event, party or activity. It seemed like all the activities were tailor-made for our class, which was nice but did not give us the chance to mix with locals.
column101: All three universities gave us evaluation forms not only at the end of each semester, but also at the end of each class. Apart from that, the main coordinator but also all the member of the consortium were available both by email and even live, if geographically that was possible. It was very easy to get access to their offices, talk to them and bring up any issue that might have arisen. Also, the secretariat was extremely helpful, replying to all requests within a maximum of 48 hours. In general there was always an easy way to bring up an issue, if needed.
column103: In my generation we made some comments about changing a few classes or professors that we found as being inadequate for the level of the program. After visiting myself the classroom of the next generation, I saw that they had already implemented changes, changed the professor and the curriculum for this class.
column104: Honestly, I think the channels are enough. The only recommendation for change that I would make would be that the consortium imforms us of how they are planning to change things, depending on our feedback, so that the change is more noticeable and tangible, because sometimes it happens within a year's time and it gets implemented only from the next generation on, without us noticing, so letting us know in advance what they are working on might be a good idea, so that we feel even more connected.
column117: I think the main issue that most Erasmus Mundus programs are facing currently is the issue of promotion, so that the programs can be sustainable in the long run, even if the number of scholarships provided are cut for financial reasons. Also, it would be nice to bring up the issue of internships, as part of the course (it currently is not necessary to do an internship to graduate). The representatives should try to raise awareness of these two issues, creating interest of other students to look for partners, sponsors and so on to cover both needs.
column118: The only aspect that I would improve would be to be a little more aware of the evaluation system in some classes. Since some of the classes were taught by more than one professor, sometimes it was not clear until the last moment how the grading would be decided.   I honestly cannot think of 2 more aspects, simply because in general I was very satisfied with the overall experience and I would repeat it, if I could.
column119: EMTM was a life-changing experience for me, which taught me not only about tourism, but life itself. I felt surrounded by an amazing team of people, whose spirit to create was shining bright and I saw places and events of the world that other people would not even dream of. I feel blessed everyday about this experience and I would relive it, if possible.

column7: EMTM - European Master in Tourism Management

column103: I feel like all our concerns have been taken into account. We have given suggestions on more practical work and field trips are now organised and used as learning opportunities. However, long-term changes will have to be evaluated by future generations since I do not know which recommendations have lead to changes of the programme that I am participating in now.
column104: There are no possible recommendations I could give. We evaluate every course individually and after the whole semester, we evaluate every university separately. column88: -Strasbourg was a catastrophe in every regard-we even had to beg for a timetable for the first week to find out where we had to go after the welcome meeting - so it should be obligatory to provide students with a fixed timetable (not as was done in Strasbourg: providing students on Monday with a timetable for the week and then changing it every day) -at every university they should help much more to find an accomodation -better information about leisure time activities -when a university participates in Erasmus Mundus, they should offer suitable language courses, which none of the three universities did -in Strasbourg we had to wait for weeks for our student card, without which we could not do literally anything and had to pay much higher prices for the public transport etc.-they should provide it at the beginning of the semester and students should not need to run after it -maybe a tour of the city with the whole class would be an idea, at least a tour of the uni, which was not offered in any of the three cities -in Udine they could not even inform us when the semester ends -in Strasbourg they are not able to give us a timetable for the last semester and cannot even tell in which weeks we have to be there and when not
column101: To the entire consortium you cannot bring up something. You would write to the secretary of the head office, after weeks you would get a very unfriendly or even aggressive answer (if you get one at all)and you would be hated by all the staff afterwards (informed through the official channels about such a case), because you dared to bring up a matter. As a student of Euroculture you do not have any rights, because "up there" they all feel like gods (which is more than true for the director in Strasbourg) and ignore what the students say. I have never experienced such a behaviour before and never met such people. Never in my life have I been treated in such ways.

column7: EUROCULTURE - Europe in the Wider World
column88: As I have little criticism to formulate towards Groningen, I will focus on Strasbourg. It would be difficult to summarize my opinion in one or two words. I believe the university has so much potential owing to its location and comprehensive program me, but there are several areas that would need improving.  1- Communication between staff and students: The person in charge has been replaced, which is good news, as he was doing an awful job, and most of the information was relayed by the students themselves. We also had several problems with one of our professors and head of the MA whose classes were extremely confusing, sloppy, and he often made last-minute changes in his program or proceedings which caused a lot of incertitude and instability. Structural changes have been made as of this term, so perhaps this will not be the case anymore. 2- General atmosphere: I think it is important to point this out. It seems abnormal that the 10 students of the first semester left Strasbourg frustrated and disappointed - nay robbed - of their money and time. While we all agree some classes were of outstanding quality (as well as their fantastic teachers), the deep-rooted structural problems, sheer lack of communication, and dismissive attitudes from some teachers dealt a severe blow to our trust in the degree. There was admittedly a strong dichotomy between the presentation of the degree ("Master of Excellence", etc) and the actual experience we had in Strasbourg. I would suggest above all a change in leadership and the destitution of the current person in charge who - we believe - in no way possessed the vital human or technical skills for his function. Again, in spite of my criticism, I would like to once more highlight the other side of story where we partook in fabulous experiences within the European Institutions, and other such outings (Paris, Metz). I still, however, believe that this is not enough, and a strong, pragmatic approach to the structural problems must be addressed before adding the final touches. Moving on, I would like to praise some of the academic staff for the outstanding quality of their classes, they definitely tipped the scale.  And finally, considering the changes that have been made (leadership, organization, cooperation with research labs such as the SAGE, etc.). I assume a great many of these issues will be solved. Strasbourg offers so many opportunities, it is without doubt an ideal location for any Euroculture student. Thank you for this opportunity.
column101: In general complaints or questions are addressed to any university coordinator and/or brought up to the higher levels.
column103: Especially regarding the University of Strasbourg, I know for a fact that substantial changes have been made (officially, we shall have to see how they are applied - it is France after all).
column118: In Strasbourg: Communication (vertical and horizontal).

column7: EUROCULTURE - Europe in the Wider World
column88: Overall I was satisfied with my experiences in Strasbourg and Groningen although the quality of courses and student life in Groningen was outstanding, I do also take into account the somewhat specific make-up of French universities, especially the limited resources they are allocated. In this regard I think it would be difficult to compare the two, even though significant efforts appear to have been made on Strasbourg's side to enhance the quality of the degree. As regards Groningen, a better housing scheme could perhaps have helped us spend less time searching for accommodation, but again, housing shortage is a well-known fact in Groningen, and through a philosophical approach I would say that I made the most of both cities/universities, each one having brought me so much. Groningen for its exceptional academic quality and resources, and Strasbourg for the proximity of European institutions, the wonderful and hands-on excursions we engaged in, and the professors, some of which were simply fantastic and with whom I learned a great deal.
column101: There are several ways, through the official online platform (at the end of each semester), and through the official meeting which takes place during the Intenseive Programme, and where representatives from each university/semester convene along with professors to discuss and comment on our experience, with a view of improving the degree in each partner university. I think this system is not only very complete but also efficient, and it left me greatly impressed!
column117: I think it's important to highlight the value of EM courses and strive to provide the same quality of services in each university to avoid imbalances occurring with more students choosing "higher ranked" universities. It's a European problem of course, as each University has different means available, but on the whole, and with regard to my personal experience, I was more than satisfied!
column118: Strasbourg: Perhaps better communication between students and professors, but also amongst professors. I know for a fact that improvements have been made along those lines, so I would not say this is still the case, and it is my pride and pleasure to have studied in such a fabulous University and in such a wonderful city that offered so many opportunities!  Groningen: The overall quality of the course at the RuG was outstanding, perhaps slightly too much of a workload, but the challenge of it was so thrilling that it's hard to say whether or not the current configuration of courses should be changed... In both cases, very satisfied with my experience there!

column88: There was a lack of information as far as visa requirements for 3rd country students. Even worse there was no effort made to help in the process,even though I was a beginner in the language. The coordinators should have a clear idea of the procedures involved for their country and if they do not know they should find out and accompany the student. There was no integration in general with the rest of either school. The student organizations were the only ones that helped with that. The Erasmus Mundus courses are separate from everyone else, making integration difficult especially when there is no orientation. Housing was also a large problem at the 1st university which greatly influenced by stay.
column101: When all the students met in Krakow for an intensive program there was a round table with the directors of each program. A representative was sent for each semester for each university. All concerns were voiced during this meeting. (I participated) I felt that most issues were dealt with and the feedback was taken into consideration by my universities in Spain and Italy. However I did notice that the southern countries of the consortium ie Italy, Spain, France were implementing changes and had more of a dialogue, but the northern countries particularly Netherlands and Germany the directors felt they knew everything. They seemed to be setting themselves as the standard for how everything should be and weren't as open to critism. I think this lack of respect as far as diversity in ways of doing things goes.
column103: I know that both of my directors have taken actions to better the program both as far as organization and content of the course. I was very pleased with that. The only outstanding issue is support for 3rd country students in which information in Italy is lacking.
column104: I think that there was a lot of dialogue about the course during it, through conversations with various professors and by end of the semester reviews. There were certain professors, especially the UK ones that took a particular interest and how things were going in the course.

column119: I feel as though overall the coordinators of the program do not care about their jobs. Or maybe they just look at is as pushing around files and keeping track of students. One coordinator even sent the next year student to me for advice about visa's even though I already had written up a document explaining how the process should go. These types of things seem lazy and a lack of concern for the students well being. Again I will say classes are organized, but outside of that, nothing.

column14: Carlos III University of Madrid and Complutense University of Madrid
column88: In Madrid the Erasmus Mundus Fusion students are isolated from other students. It would be nice if this was not the case.
column101: I would have to email and have correspondence directly with the main coordinator and secretariat of my master. I and others was dissatisfied with the education and teaching practised in Madrid. We then wrote a letter to the local coordinators in Madrid.
column103: One professor in Madrid could not speak English. Having him teaching a course in English was very problematic. My year, and previous years have pointed out this issue, but he is still teaching the course.
column104: The feedback system in Madrid is very weak. It consists of checkboxes, asking for the degree of satisfaction in areas unrelated to the problems in Madrid. Also the academic culutre in Madrid is such that the professors are above the students, and cannot be criticized by inferior students. It would be better to do a meeting/session. Where everybody openly discusses the past year.
column118: The academic level in Spain needs to be improved, by enforcing structure and organization. The courses do not have a curriculum/syllabus, so the experience is mostly students attending to lectures. It is very difficult for students to study, because students are not provided with litterature and exercises/problems. The erasmus mundus students do not have courses with the local spanish students, but seperate courses in English. Many of these courses seems improvised and badly prepared. Also they are plauged with problems such as professors not able to speak english, and professors who instead of teaching plays cards with us, or watch youtube clips with us. It seems that nobody forces the spanish professors to organize a good course, that benefits the erasmus mundus students. The single most important aspect of my student experience that must be improved is: Someone must enforce structure and organization on the courses in Madrid, so it meets the high standarts that I am currenlty enjoying at Gent University.

The biggest problem is that the coordinating university is the source of most weaknesses in the program.
column104: (1) Actually listen to your students' concerns and then act on them (in order to gain students' trust;  (2) Give the programme representative respect/status (take them seriously); and (3) Don't become defensive as soon as any criticism is levied against you; this defeats the entire purpose of the feedback process and disincentivizes students from giving feedback at all, let alone honest feedback.
column117: Course quality and effective addressing of student concerns. For this particular course, student mobility policy needs to be seriously reviewed and amended - it has led to considerable upset and frustration for many students and has had significant implications for future career prospects for at least a dozen students (already way too many).
column118: 1) Clear, open communication with an actually responsive coordinator. 2) Clear instructions/guidelines/policies on the course structure, expectations, degree validity etc. 3) Consistency between approaches/policies across the consortium partners and within each university even.  The gap/discrepancy in quality between the University of East Anglia and all other consortium partners is massive and creates an unfair/unequal dimension to the quality of education that each student receives.

column88: Just think how you would like to be treated when you change every 5-7 months residence, country... May be a welcome lunch with a debate of questions to coordinators...
column101: The student should knock a door of a coordinator and hope that he/she is there and if so, whether he/she has time. Mostly no time and bad faces instead of help. Normally it takes many emails before you get some help. You are hardly helped out, normally the opposite.
column103: - Comments were done about some professors and courses in ICT Prague and those lo quality couses and professors have not been improved or changed
column104: - Interest by the coordination (on the whole) not just that one person from one institute is willing to help at times but finds it impossible when others from the same or other institutions and a higher range prefer to give this master and its students one of the last positions among his/her priorities.  - Avoid gossips: private students information, such as thesis, scores, health... should be confidentially kept by the coordination.  - Trust in coordination depends on actions that they take and in how much or less they are willing to help. Normally students have to beg for help. - Class representatives should be chosen in public, not by email...
column117: - The great lack of supervision during Master thesis research (we were treated as if we were doing a PhD, left alone mostly), especially (but not only) when going out of Europe. There are no exceptions, all cases that went out of Europe felt that they were left alone in the middle of the dark. Why? Because supervisorss from Europe did not avoid it, did not ask us how was it going and were only concerned about the good relation with their contact abroad and the possible publications... it was slavery. People were forced to do tasks such as just washing up in the lab, sweep, follow a master student that permanently failed the experiment which never worked for more than 15 days during the 7 months of stay, etc.  During my MSc thesis two people left the lab (one bachelors or master student and one PhD student) because they could not stand anymore the lab responsible, it was a dictatorship regime, changes and modifications in projects were forced and decided by that person only, no agreements were made. It was quite a hell to stay there. Everybody was stressed out and putting up with daily humiliating comments from the responsible such as: "This is my lab and that is what I want, whenever you have a lab you can do whatever you want", "I am always right, right?", "PhD students have priorities over master students", that person made people cry in the lab, cancelled many weekly appointments with all students and those were the only following up with some people. Others, had not even weekly appointments and had to request appointments.
column118: - Lectures at the beginning at UNESCO-IHE were very general, not for Master students but for Bachelors´s 1st year or even high school. Though, the last courses, such as GIS and Statistics were put at the end with great time constrictions to comple tasks in due time. Statistics (known as one of the hardest disciplines) was give in less that 10 days and just finished less that one week before the exam. There were lectures of that subject morning and afternoon for about 7 days very fast and impossible to follow.   - General English level, knowledge and especially motivation at ICT Prague was pathetic, there is much to be improved in that university if they want to keep international - At Ghent University: access to professors needed an appointment and exam revisons was very dramatic, they were just not willing to show you the exam
column119: - Professors at ICT Prague should: 1- Improve their English 2- Explain with some motivation 3- Pepare lectures better 4- Organize what is importat and focus on important things to be explained (this goes for one of the most interesting courses: Environmental Microbiology in which there was too much material that was just reduced at the end and Wastewater Treatment in which the history of Prague sewers was very well and slowly explained at the beginning while types of reactors was very basic and had to be  mostly completed with the use of internet or books at the very end. Also for the latter, there was a complete lack of practical exercises and calculation, I wonder why)

column88: It would be very useful if Ghent University would provide any support to the students especially in the matter of health issues, in my case I got none. No any explanation regarding grading system and evaluation system has been provided as well.
column101: Prof. Van Huylenbroeck personal opinion had serious influence on my exams final grades, I failed his two exams (after I completed with excellent grades MS in Norway!). Besides that he categorically refused to let me re take (as other students) these exams in Nitra where I had summer case and  I had only 2 days in first term for preparation, after I have been in hospital, and 2 days in 2 term after summer case, this is far from the normal study conditions. And I have been expelled from the program based on that. I'm sorry, but educational standards can not based on personal opinion (likes, dislikes) of one person. I will continue to make attention to my case in order to prevent other students to select the Ghent University and particular Prof. Van Huylenbroeck as study co-ordinator. And I would like to thank people whom organized Nitra summer case for great practical study experience, since I weren't gave chance for study in Berlin, Nitra study have been only positive experience in IMRD.
column103: The previous year students said to me that they even shared to ask questions to coordinator Prof. Van Huylenbroeck in order not to get from him "too much attention", other way they afraid to failed his courses. column104: To hear the students feedback- is to break the IMRD system which exist already so many years, I honestly don't think that anything will  changing here. column117: The overall issue amongst several EMA courses namely the bureaucratic difficulty of actually getting your degree after passing all courses& handing in the thesis. This takes on average 9 months. Measured across 3 diff EMA programs. As a good friend of mine said about her EMA course: "The Master was doable, the bureacratic paperwork afterwards to get my actual diploma was hell"

column7: MAMASELF - Master in material science exploring European large scale facilities

column7: MAMASELF - Master in material science exploring European large scale facilities
column88: I feel a little harsh criticizing TUM for housing and language courses as the Universities in Munich simply don't have enough housing or language courses for the numbers of students they accept- not really a fault of the course. That said, being more clear that students have to be very proactive in seeking out these resources would be beneficial. In addition, Munich didn't baby us- they expected (rightly) for us to take the information given and use it to sort ourselves out. Rennes organised everything for us. In Germany we were forced to adapt to the local culture, in France we had everything organised for us... Partly a result of language barriers but still was good I think to learn to fit into a new system.
column101: The best, and fastest method would be via e-mailing one or more of the organisers- or alternately e-mailing a secretary and asking for anonymity.
column104: At Rennes there were clear requests for feedback regarding how the programme was conducted, Munich also had feedback channels but could benefit from being a bit more vocal about them.
column118: Credit transfer from Rennes to TUM could have been significantly improved by greater clarity and coordination between both parties- though I was the first to do the full thesis at TUM so difficulties are to be expected and likely have improved. More help with accommodation in Munich would have improved the lives of many, though I was lucky to have avoided to many issues with this. Finally greater coordination with Alumni would have made it easier for younger years, though the switch to the two year system makes it much easier to accomplish this, and I am confident that my year helped the second year significantly.

However, in professional aspect, I did not receive too much professional assistance in theatrical field because I have learn in the university of Taiwan; in practical field, there was a little more help than theatrical field because practical experience can not learn from papers. Therefore, except the certificate paper of the master program and the enrichment of experience through personal exchange, there is no much essential improvement in professional field.

column7: MCEMESV: MASTER CONJOINT ERASMUS MUNDUS EN ETUDE DU SPECTACLE VIVANT
column88: Mostly the integration stays as an student's task because the organization of the master as a conjoint programme is not well known by all the workers of the university and this is translated in always having administrative problems because the program is an "especial case" that nobody knows how to deal with.
column101: I have no idea
column104: To have somebody in charge that is really willing to care about students and to make a fluid communication channel with the rest of the departments of the university and with the articulation from one university to the other. If the staff of the university never knows how to deal with our situation and more precisely of the points that yourself you're remarking in this survey it becomes really difficult to arrange everything for each student. These are the great weaknesses of the program and the fact that students come from all over the world to get in the middle of the unknown and to be completely out of support in a strong variety of situations is really dangerous and stressful.
column118: support to administrative procedures, communication between the universities in the consortium and orientation about the housing,immigration, living expenses, etc. in the beginning might be really useful.
column119: Usually there is just one person in charge of Erasmus Mundus students in each university and often, they are overwhelmed with a lot of different tasks to do and not always available to help students. Sometimes i've been misinformed because the person in charge was just trying to get rid of the problem without having to go farer.

column7: MCEMESV: MASTER CONJOINT ERASMUS MUNDUS EN ETUDE DU SPECTACLE VIVANT
column88: For the first University (Paris 8) and the last one (Nice Sophia Antipolis) the integration had been realised in a very profesional and profoundly human manner. For the second one (ULB) it could have been improved by a more organised welcoming (no one helped us for the orientation: our arrival wasn't announced, therefore our documents have been ready only after two months, containing several errors). It could have been improved also by a deeper implication of the coordinators in our university-related problems and by a clearer separation of the reseponsabilities of each persons involved in the programme.
column101: I never asked such information, but if I would need to contact the entire consortium I would ask my coordinator which are the steps I should follow.
column103: I don't have any information regarding the recommendations given by students.
column104: Contacting them directly by mail after each semester/year, organising reunions in each University, choosing a leader to transmit the feedback.
column118: This experience was, overall, an amazing, powerful and motivating one. The only aspects that needs improvement are the ones realted to the Université Libre de Bruxelles - 1. the administrative, 2. organisational and 3. the humanely ones. Our basic needs and demands weren't met, causing a distresful period and the dificulty to fulfill our students tasks by not having acces to the information, not having an efficient reaction to our feedback and having to solve logistic problems that weren' our responsability. If the communication, the implication or the empathy of each member could be improved, each student could enjoy and benefit from the enormous potential ULB has.
column119: Introducing more reunions or a news-letter by mail with all the information about each programme, during the studies, would help the students to stay informed and to meet to share ideas and suggestions.

column118: the comunication with the coordination of the programe, the coordination between the universities, the balance betwen the level of the teaching (for exemple, the university paris 8 is far forward in its teaching program related tu the universidad de sevilla and université libre de bruxelles).
column119: I had the impression that the Master were not an important project for the universities, maybe there is a financial problem... but the most of teachers and administration personal wasen't invested in the erasmus mundus master. I realy apreciate the experience beacause I met new and interesting people and lived in new countries, but in terms of academic level, knowledge and creation it was far from being good, it was mostly the case with the Université libre de Bruxelles and the Universidad de Sevilla.

column118: the first and not the least is organisation
column119: When I came to my first university I was told that I should come to the residence and pay for the month and for insurance. I came from Russia with a luggage, in the residence I was told that they don't know me and I shouldn't be there. I had no idea that I should have payed by checks only etc. So, I should have slept on the street with all my stuff. Only the girl on the reception helped me. She read ALL emails from my coordiantor and told me that it's not my fault. Anyway, I came there with a very poor knowledge of language (because before consortium ignored all my language certificates that I have sent), so the connection with french people in english didn't really work. I stayed 4 days at my friends' friend place (luckily I found them before I came there). And only after that i got to the residence. My coordiantor in Nice haven't ever replied on all my calls and messages. She WAS ON HOLIDAYS. And I was totally lonely in a country, the language I don't know. etc.  All my collegues could tell one hudred stories like that.  Students don't have any integration course. Nobody tell us about form of academic work, methodology, etc. Money are spent on some stuff that are not connected to erasmus mundus student integration.  Students feel themeselves in  classes like guests and all professors treat us as we were on the excursion there. etc, etc, etc

column117: Since payments of scholarship are made  after scholarship students arrives at the university, it may get hard for them specially for those who came from developing countries. Meaning, payments are made late after opening of a bank account so if a student don't have enough money until the payment is made, he/she may suffer due to financial stress. I can be a good example for this. I came to UK to study the masters only bringing £600, but accommodation payment of £1500 have to be made for the term. In addition paying for living expenses like food, clothing, transport is also hard since I was told the scholarship payments will be made after one month and two weeks after arrival at the university.
column118: Payments of Scholarships should be fast especially for developing country students. There should be a programme to visit the historical or cultural places of each university attended so a student know the culture of the country.
