column7: MEEES - Masters in Earthquake Engineering and Engineering Seismology
column88: Orientation in University 1 (UJF) was totally great with respect to all aspects. Orientation in University 2 (ROSE School) was given one month and a half after I arrived, i.e. already after the first course had ended and I had already had my first exam. Orientation should take place within the first week. By the time I had it, I had already struggled to collect that information from classmates who had started here from the first semester. Examples of contrast between the two universities (U1 and U2): Bank: U1 sent us to the bank with personnel from the Int. Relations office in order to do all the procedures. U2 just told me "go to any bank" (and I went by myself). Health: U1 told us what to do in case of needing medical assistance. When I specifically asked how the health insurance worked on email, U2 simple said "go to the hospital", whithout even  saying which hospital, if there was more than one hospital in town, etc.
column101: I believe he/she should email the Secretariat of the Consortium, or address the Academic Coordinator of the place he/she is currently at.
column104: University 2 requests students to fill in evaluation forms at the end of each course but, for example, one of the questions is related to the adequacy of the grading... and they ask you to fill in the form as a requirement to be informed that course's grade... how would one now if the grading is adequate if you haven't seen how the grading is carried out yet?
column118: (1) When I was still at home, before coming to Europe, it was very difficult to understand if I needed to ask for one or two Visas before coming, or if I should just take the one for the first country and then take a second one for the other country while already being at the first one... (Please note that I acquired the Italian citizenship after finishing my Master, so I needed Visas for both countries). I asked, and the answers were not clear (not even in the Italian Consulate, until I finally managed to talk to the Italian person issuing visas in my country, who told me he could not issue a visa for me 6 months in advance, and that I should contact the Italian Consulate in France when I got there. But the whole process of trying to figure this out was painful. (2) The schedule regarding first orientation meetings and beginning of academic activities was sent to me less than one month before leaving Argentina... I had asked when exactly I was suppossed to arrive to France, and got as an answer (from the main Secretariat, not from UJF) to look at the courses' schedule. But the schedule just said generic dates. For people needing to buy expensive plane tickets, it'd be useful to know in advance the exact date at which their presence is required (I just assumed a date and bought it). (3) In University 2, it would have been useful to have a meeting in which professors/researchers offered thesis topics to students. I know they started doing it in the years after me.
column119: Even though it might seem that I'm taking it too hard regarding some organizational issues, I really enjoyed the programme and I'll always be thankful for this amazing opportunity that certainly changed my life for the best. My comments regarding logistics aim at helping future students who will probably face the same doubts I faced and for which it was difficult to find answers. Once I arrived to Europe, I began to understand how things worked and everything got easier, but there are many topics regarding which the Universities could provide valuable information in the months before starting the programme (specially regarding immigration issues for those travelling from far away). It would also be useful to make the process of communicating the admission results something common to all Erasmus Mundus programmes. I had actually applied to two programmes (the other one was the SAHC), and they had different times to communicate partial and final admission results, so it was quite hard when having to choose between the two, because SAHC was always clearer in the way they communicated with me, while MEEES was just telling me that I was "eligible" for a scholarship, while what they really meant was that I had already been awarded it, in case I confirmed I was taking that one and no other Erasmus Mundus one. All this was quite confusing.

column7: MEME - Erasmus Mundus Master Programme in Evolutionary Biology
column88: Within each university, we usually had a good welcome, even if some universities did not orgnized an integration week(or there was but we were not arriving at the right time as other international students). What SHOULD be improved is the presentation of the master, which listed a huge number of courses... which in fact we could not attend. I choose this master because there were courses in Ecology listed. I could not take any, because we could not choose our courses. Saying which courses are actually available would be a huge improvment.  Everything was not perfect everywhere (Montpellier is much less used to welcoming international students than Uppsala, clearly), but in general, I would say we were treated very well, faculty and administrators were very helpful and gave us numerous advices. The summer school at the begining of each year, with all coordinators (and later, former students) was a great help as one can ask every questions.  Possible improvment : maintaning forums for a given university with all information available. As students, we created a wiki, filling it as we get new info, tips, advices for new students.
column101: He would ask the other students and elected representatives for their opinions, and a letter (as a mail form) would be sent to all coordinators.
column103: For many, they have. As it was the first year the consortium existed, it was very important. The description of the courses was an exception, though, and a bad one. But otherwise, I would say that I felt that they really were listening to our feedbacks, asking for them regularly, and trying to improve. Even if there was no formal way, I was feeling quite free to discuss the problematic matters with any of our coordinators, and I did it when needed. During the summer schools, a whole session was dedicated to feedbacks.
column104: Montpellier should be advised to have an official feedback system. So far, everything was being done through student representative, direct discussions with coordinators or course examinators, or enquiries set up by students/teachers themselves (so they got feedback, but there is no official, university wide system).
column118: * The category A and B students should get the same amount of money, except for the travel expense. 500 euros is not enough to live in France/Sweden/Netherlands. 750 is possible. 1000 is *more than enough*. It creates two types of students, with different lifestyles, some of them can barely do anything while the others can have a lot of fun travelling around. For no obvious reason. It should be noted that in many case, it's very difficult to get a student job, as we don't speak the country langage (in Sweden, it's impossible, in France it's very, very hard), plus we get quite involved in courses (language courses in the evening) and projects.  * European rules concerning externat projects should be stated more clearly, from the begining, and in the master webstite.  * Coordinators could coordinate more and not give different answers to the same question.
column119: I knew when begining this master that is was its first year of existence, and that as a result, there would be a lot of problems, questions, and arising difficulties that could not be foreseen. I was aware of that and I accepted it. Actually, it did not go as roughly as I expected, given the fact that four (five) universities are exchanging students, with different rules, organizations, semesters, laws, phylosophies. In conclusion, it as an extraordinary experience. Our coordinators did their best, and even when it fell short on one or two points, they still did a wonderful job most of the time and that should be noted.

In all the three universities, I feel a general lacking of integrating us to native student lives and universities events , which could be caused by the language barriers.

University of Groningen asked us to select a mentor, but it's not very practical and basically not in use .  - each universities has quite different calendars from  each other , which might sometimes cause inconvenience and stress in moving.  - different universities have different requirements for obtaining a degree and we need to have two degrees to finish the master.. sometimes it's confusing and can make it cumbersome to make decisions in choosing universities

column7: MEME - Erasmus Mundus Master Programme in Evolutionary Biology
column88: At University 2 (in France), the administrative staff did not speak English. The course/program coordinators were very helpful, but is was still a bit of a struggle to arrange everything like administration and housing. However I don't know how this could be improved much, since the administrative staff simply does not speak English.
column101: There were student speakers at each university, who could bring problems to the attention of the consortium. Alternatively one could send an email to all the course coordinators at the different universities. One could also talk to the administrative coordinator, who was always very helpful, and who would address our concerns to the rest of the consortium.
column103: I was a member of the first cohort of students. Understandably, there were still a lot of problems that came up. Recommendations given by the students were sometimes addressed well, but not always. My impression was that the coordinators had a very strong intention to help, but due to a lack of time not all recommendations could be addressed. My main issue is that it sometimes took a long time before we would get more information about regulations regarding for example mobility or credits. This would create unnecessary confusion among the students, or wrong expectations and disappointments. For practical problems, such as visa or housing issues, help was always readily available.
column104: My main recommendation would be to increase communication among the coordinators at the different universities. The coordinators were all individually approachable, but they would not always give you the same answer to questions, creating confusion. Also, if the coordinators would coordinate their response more, it would also be easier to distribute the workload (of for example making a new program guide). This may decrease the time it takes to implement a recommendation.
column117: The availability of accurate information concerning the program as a whole, and the courses and living at the different universities at all times.
column118: 1) Communication about rules and regulations concerning mobility and credits requirements. More specifically, communication about these issues should be in time, and should be unambiguous. 2) Implementation of received feedback and recommendations. 3) It would be great if the semester times at the different universities would match up better, which would make planning and mobility easier (for example, there should not be a very big or very small gap between semesters). Also, the first semester with courses is now much longer in Groningen than in Uppsala, though the students get the same number of credits. This is not fair and creates frustration among the students.
column119: Overall, it was a really great program and I would definitely do it again. I liked the general enthusiastic atmosphere, the high scientific quality of the program and the high mobility. I feel like I got a lot of opportunities to do research and meet faculty and students from many different countries.

column119: The MEME program is a success. It was definitely the best decision to take part of it, and every year it attracts more applications and good attention around the world for its quality. The program is still young, and as such in a building process that involves administrative disagreements. Neverheless, every year the different universities make adjustments to make it better, which do need adequate funding. I would say the only problems that have arisen in the latter period come from funding being cut down. The program is doing its best with what it has, and gives excellent personalized attention to the best of their capabilities, in addition to the top quality education and research it puts together.

column88: Compared to universities 1 and 3, university 2 didn't have any form of welcoming programme/orientation or integration experience and I found it very hard to settle into the country. This had a hugely detrimental on my experience of the country so that I will not go back there in the foreseeable future despite having enjoyed visits there in the past.
column101: We are all in contact with each via Facebook and email. For formal matters and subject could be discussed during our annual summer school when all students on the programme, the course coordinators and representatives from each partner university are present.
column104: None, the current system works well from what I have seen.
column117: I don't know from what I have heard from my programme's EMA course representative the MEME programme appears to be one of the best functioning Erasmus Mundus masters programmes compared to the problems raised by representatives from other programmes. On that matter I believe I am getting a spectacular level of education and value for money compared to my home country. Hence I guess my answer would be the quality of the programme and how it enhances the employability of the students enrolled upon it.
column118: I would improve the pastoral support for students who find it difficult to settle in to the new countries that they visit. This could take the form of a casual conversation between each student and a member of the universities faculty involving a simple question, "Are you happy here?". When I was in France during my time at university 2 I suffered from culture shock that lead to me becoming very depressed and feeling like I had no one to talk to. I didn't want to insult my teachers by discussing the problem with them as it would have appeared to be a long rant about what I disliked in their country. But if someone had asked me simply whether I was happy I could have just said "no" and the situation could have been dealt with. Instead I dealt with it by forming a social group solely out of British expats, which alleviated my culture shock but by no means integrated me into french culture or dealt with the issue.
column119: I should point out that when I went to Harvard I received leaflets and information in how to deal with culture shock as part of my international student registration pack. This time I have been fortunate enough not to experience culture shock again.

column88: Housing was a difficult issue at both universities. I would appreciated more information at Uppsala about the very different standards of housing in different places. Also, in Munich, it would have been nice if there had been more places reserved for students of Erasmus Mundus programs, as Munich is very difficult with housing.
column101: Write an Email to the Coordinator directly or discuss the matter with their elected student representative first.
column103: Every year at summer school there was a long meeting of the entire board of the programme with the students / student representatives discussing all issues that had come up during the year. Of course, progress can be slow in such large consortiums when it comes to organisational issues across borders, but our concerns were always heard and set on the agenda for the coming year.
column104: It might be useful to have a staff member of the consortium elected to specifically represent all student's interests, thus avoiding conflicts between different universities' administrations in certain matters.
column117: Scholarships! It did make absolutely no sense that Non-European students were given scholarships worth far more than twice as much as European students. The intention clearly is to enable students from abroad to study in Europe, however it makes no sense to give someone from a well-off family in e.g. the US a lot of money they don't need while European students from poor families hardly get enough to fund their studies. Also, not throwing just as much money at students from abroad would enable to increase the number of European scholarships.
column118: 1. Fairness of scholarship money It just doesn't make sense to throw tons of money at rich kids from Non-European countries. Rather distribute the scholarships such that everybody can live off them, Non-European or European. 2. Grades It would be nice if universities of a consortium could agree on a grading system which they could implement in parallel to the national grading systems, so that everybody could have one joint transcript of their grades throughout their studies. 3. Visas It did personally not affect me, but every non-EU student had to go through major pains to be allowed to go to different countries of the partner universities. That's just plain ridiculous! One visa for the entire two years and the entire EU should be enough.
column119: I'd like to add that I really enjoyed my studies in MEME and I wouldn't wanna have missed it for the world! Best two years of my life, professionally and personally! I hope Erasmus Mundus programs will be around for a long time to come.

column118: More flexibility and personalized study plans according to students track.   More focus on the program´s mobility structure (especially since there are not so many students in the program) Seems like each university study plan works very independently complicating student´s course plan.  Creating a community and network of all involved student in our program (MERIT) would have been nice. I know other programs have this activities and yearly meetings.
column119: I felt there was no flexibility or personal academic guidance in my study plan. Upon arrival at my 1st university (KIT) I was given a list of mandatory courses (50 out of 60 credits) with a tough warning of "no negotiation" for all MERIT students regardless of our track. And this list belonged to an already existing program at KIT. I felt it was too unflexible and there was no opportunity to define a study plan with coordinator (as it was said we would in MERIT progam website), which would have given me a stronger knowledge in my track and on the career path i want to follow. Instead, I had to take mostly compulsory courses and now almost after completing 90 credits i don´t feel i have enough specialization in my track.  At 2nd year (KTH) there was more flexibility and better personalized attention but then interesting courses in my track where in spring where I will already be doing my thesis.  Also I sometimes felt at KIT that instead of being a privilege to belong to an EM program (which i know it is ) it felt like we were just one more exchange student in a foreign university.  On the good side, both administrative coordinators at KIT and KTH were really helpful and attentive with everything that came up. I really thank them.

column103: We were the first batch which was able to organize a feedback session for all members of our department to draw attention to issues which concerned our student body. Unfortunately, feedback was not really welcome. Instead faculty members such as our course coordinator would try to shift the discussion on a personal level.  Recommendations of how to improve the program are not heard and shut down. Serious matter of concern are swept under the carpet. Just disappointing.
column104: I recommend to remove the course coordinator Aleh cherp as soon as possible. He is not taking his job serious and not even on site, since he is living in Sweden (program takes place in Budapest). Taking into consideration that the ERASMUS programs cost millions of taxpayer money, I would urgently recommend a service hotline where serious concerns can be addressed which the university is not taking seriously. It's all about reputation but not about teaching quality. I would urge you to significantly improve the feedback system for the sake of future students which all have to battle the same problems at CEU/Uni. of Agean/Manchester in MESPOM
column118: 1. Class coordinations 2. Teaching quality 3. Real Feedback system
column119: Recommendations and feedback should be given to an independent ERASMUS Board. Third, professors should check their e-mails properly before we pick our supervisors for thesis writing. Although I was extremely happy for my supervision in Manchester and very glad to stay there for my thesis, before I decided to go there and when I did not have any supervisors at that time, I communicated with two other professors from CEU, and I have never received a response regarding my requests although I sent my inquiries a way before the thesis rush has started  among the students, and personally I do not think that it is a professional behaviour.

column7: MESPOM - Master of Science in Environmental Sciences, Policy and Management
column88: The orientation and integration experience could have been improved simply by making it a priority to have faculty and staff introduce themselves to our class. At all orientations, I felt that we were just another batch of students and little effort was made to make our experience personal and welcoming. By giving a clear schedule and allocating time for Q & A would have helped tremendously.
column101: In order to bring up a matter to the entire consortium you would have to first speak with the course coordinator Aleh  Cherp. After a couple of answered emails, keeping a persistent mind, and marking the email as urgent, you make get a short response. However, very little will actually resolve the matter unless you involve other faculty or staff who can also address the issue on your behalf.
column103: After the first 3 months of our course, the student body was extremely unhappy with the way the course was being managed. Our concerns were not being heard. Instead, they were being outright ignored and even deleted by the course coordinator on our course's online forum.  We addressed this to Central European University and our course coordinator but the response was poor. During a 2 hour meeting arranged by the student body, the course coordinator Aleh Cherp got hostile and had to be calmed down by the department head Alan Watt. We gave feasible and appropriate suggestions of which only 1 was taken into consideration (for the following cohort).
column104: Immediately replace the course coordinator with an individual more suitable and reliable. Enforce a standardized feedback forum after 2 months of the course and/or create a hotline or provide a number for students to express their concerns about the management of the course.

column119: There was little communication between the universities. Therefore, course material was repeated often and resulted in surfaced teaching.

column88: The British education system is substantially different from that of Europe, thus, any EM consortium that includes a British university should take this into account. We were denied legal help from the university, council and related bodies for housing related issues since we were Erasmus students in the UK. Also, the courses offered at University of Manchester along with the students quality at the university is substantially lower than that of other universities in the consortium. Please do take this into consideration when requiring EM students to take courses with other students

column7: MISOCO - Joint European Master in International Migration and Social Cohesion
column88: The most important thing, as a scholarship holder, was to get the scholarship funds within a month of arriving. We were not advised "you need your BSN (Social Security number for Holland) ASAP otherwise you don't get paid". A lot of people applied for this BSN late, and then found out it was required for payment. I personally lost a lot of money constantly transfering funds from my home country. I was also lending money out to other students in my program who didn't have any money until the scholarship was deposited. We really need to informed when we arrive what we need to do to get out scholarship within the first month, before major payments like rent are due.

column88: In case of University of Lleida (among a lot of other things) I think that orientation for foreign students should be given in English, and personnel who are working in International Office also should speak English.
column101: I presume that the easiest way would be to ask planning officer of the entire programme(in case that I cannot find the contact by myself).
column103: From conversation with previous students it can be seen that the consortium is making effort to change things every year. I do not know how they are checking does each of the involved Universities is implementing students suggestions, but it seems that some of the Universities are not interested of making any changes. This doesn't seem fair because in the 2nd year we have to be equally distributed per University, and in some of them the things that we hear in the presentations and the actual situation are completely different things, and often can be really bad.
column104: The easiest way would be to make a forum page at each University related only to this particular programme so that we can gain some insight from the student's point of view. This would also make a lot difference in decision-making were to go for 2nd year (really important in this programme).
column118: 1. In the 1st year we had 3 month of applied period in Institutes/Companies related to the field of study, but descriptions on which we are choosing where to go are general and at the end some of us got the work that was not expected or described at all. 2. Considering that this 2 year Master programme is supposed to be in English, University of Lleida (my 2nd year host University) should make an effort to fins professors who are able to give proper lectures in English, because there was a lot of moments when nobody understood what is going on in classes, and also going on field trip with Spanish students is meaningless if we don't speak the language. 3. It would be nice if the supervisors responsible for the programme during the 2nd year should pay more attention to students that come there (again related to University of Lleida, I don't know about the rest of Universities). Giving some information related to administration issues (e.g. what are student's responsibilities related to paper signing after thesis defense), more details about the courses, and especially not making a choice of thesis supervisor a fait accompli would make studying there more enjoyable and they would be oh higher quality. Considering that the University is choosing who will come there for the 2nd year to write a master thesis and one can say to specialize in certain field, they made it really hard to do it in a proper way.
column119: I think it would be great if there is any way to make feedback compulsory for both students and professor related to the work that has been done. I was in a situation when I asked one professor (twice) on feedback related to the work that I have done for his course, and he never replied. If they don't want to tell us how to improve our work, where are we making mistakes, etc., I really don't see the point of education.

column7: MScEF - Master of Science in European Forestry
column88: In case of University of Eastern Finland I have no objections at all, while in case of University of Lleida  they should seriously consider that foreign students do not speak Spanish language upon arrival.
column101: I am not sure how would this work, but me personally (if I am enable to find it by myself) would ask the contact from fellow students or the coordinating University for contact, and write to the consortium.
column103: It is evident that improvements were made according to suggestions made by previous student. I think that consortium is really making an effort to improve quality of studies, but at some of the Universities there are a lot of discrepancies between the presentations and actual situation when you arrive there. I do not know how the evaluation of each University is done or what are the criteria to be enrolled, however some of them are not showing any interest in students and maybe they should be revised.
column104: In order to give the felling of anonymity to students, feedback should be done in electronic form, so the idea of doing the feedback in the middle of the ongoing course, in the classroom, feeling the form by hand (although we do not write our names) does not fell proper. This is completely subjective opinion, but when you hear comments from professors that are related to your feedback, it really does not make any sense of doing it.

column15: University of Pompeu Fabra and University of Barcelona
column118: The three universities should communicate more and try to make the program more coherent.
column119: Even though I have the grant and I consider that I have been working hard, some of the people with grant were only interested in travelling and not doing much work. Considering we had a lot of group works it was specially unfair for people who didn't have a grant, who were not gettitng paid (but were paying for the studies) and had to do more work. The thing was that half of the class was from Spain and there were only two grants for the Spanish people, so  most of them didn't have a grant. But because the program was in Spanish, they also had extrawork correcting non-native  writting, which was also unfair. I suggest that it somehow be controled what people with grant do and what they don't do, since some of them were taking the year almost as paid holidays, often didn't attend class or did almost nothing in the group works. Also, the people without grant were normally not asked to give their opinion about the program, which is also very unfair.

column119: Mobility: The ambiance among students in my program has not been so good because of competition for some mobility destinations. The mobility track of the students could be decided and fixed before they start the course.  EU students should be obliged to be in 2 EU countries aside from their country of origin. Non-EU students should be allowed to do internship in a non-EU member university of the consortium for a maximum period of 3 months. I find it absurd that the coordinating university impedes the latter while not obliging Spanish students to be in 2 EU countries other than Spain.

column119: -it is difficult to get visa for non-EU students. Consortium Univesties should pay more attention to this issue. -About students with disabilities. Once I ve got sick the MAPP Consortium asked me to refuse from my scholarship for 5 months (because I wanted to take medical treatment at my home country). I refused from my scholarship as it was asked. From the legal point of view this decision of MAPP Consortium was correct, but in sense of humanity and attitude to students with disabilities or health problems this is not  correct or even inhuman. This is not about money, but about attitude. So person have an impression that the program is interested in us and our academic work if we successfull and healthy enough,but not when we could get sick. Now I am fine, after treatment and Iam studying at IBEi and starting from september again receive my scholarship, but do not want any other student experience such attitude during the period sickness and recovery. In general, I wish to mention that more understanding and better attitude to students with disabilities needed. -students also in need of help or any assistance with publication of their scientific works.

I also think course representatives should work closely together and with the other Consortium representative to ensure that there is more continuity, both academically and logistically, between the first and second year of the program.
column118: - logistical issues (particularly visa issues in the second year and the lack of coordination of health plans between the first and second year which can cause certain conditions to not be covered if they emerged in the first year of the program). - The order of the academic content. Many courses taken in the second year should in fact have been introductory classes given in the first year, while many of the first year classes should have been given in second year).  - There should also be more coordination between the first year academic counselling and the second year so that the final result (thesis) can incorporate all the material learned over two years. In my case we had to write two thesis and there was little interaction or continuity between both years.
column119: In my first year, the academic counseling was outstanding and I felt that there were many resources (apart from my supervisor and second reader) to draw from and that were happy to give feedback. In my second year, the process felt more bureaucratic. Supervisors were assigned and second readers were not revealed. At each seminar, there were different professors and students who gave feedback, which made the process and feedback feel somewhat superficial as they had not followed any of the other debates surrounding your topic and each time the presentation started from the basics.

column119: Although funding may constrain further recruitment than current number, what I have achieved and received so far attest to the usefulness of the Erasmus Mundus programmes. Honestly, without such support I could not have studied in Europe and all I have acquired now would have existed in me. I suggest the Commission tries its best to recruit more especially from Africa which needs such prepared minds for development. Moreover, I suggest to the Commission that there should be country specific programmes. A Research Committee could be established to review developing countries based on their pressing needs to recruit more students for such programmes from those countries.

column7: MUNDUS MAPP - Erasmus Mundus Master's in Public Policy
column88: From an administrative and information standpoint, IBEI - my second year university - has been an unqualified catastrophe from top to bottom, to the point where I would not hesitate to recommend AGAINST them as an option for future MUNDUS MAPP students and have even considered encouraging the MAPP consortium and the Erasmus Mundus program overall to sever the relationship with IBEI, or at least not renew any partnership with the institute in the future.  Let us begin at the beginning.  In May of this year, those of us Mundus MAPP students continuing at IBEI in our second year received an e-mail from the administrators welcoming us to the program and promising us further information (stated as "next week"), specifically on the visa and immigration process and procedures. We received NO information - none at all - on those or any other issues for THE REST OF THE SUMMER (forget "next week.")  When we were finally provided with information on the immigration process, it came in the form of an e-mail sent on the very last day of July, an e-mail which included the revelation that IBEI would be closed from August 1-25. In other words: here's the info you need, but if you have any questions about it (or anything else for that matter), sorry, we'll be closed for the month by the time you even read this message.  We received no information about when classes started, coursework, course expectations, or anything else that you might expect from a university setting, before the end of August.  At some point over the summer, a few of us noticed that the academic calendar on the IBEI website had been updated to the 2013-2014 academic year. That calendar included dates of September 9-20 for a series of "pre-session" courses. Assuming that this was mandatory, and lacking any information otherwise, a number of us planned our arrivals to Barcelona in order to accommodate those dates. It was only after arriving, and visiting IBEI in person, that I was informed that we did not, in fact, have to attend the pre-session.  E-mails on even the most basic administrative questions go unanswered for weeks and weeks on end. I personally began e-mailing IBEI in June of this year asking questions about banking and the administration of my EM scholarship. It took five weeks and three e-mails - the third one CC'd to the administration at my first year university, CEU, which also coordinates the Mundus MAPP program - before I finally received a reply.  Every step of the way, information from IBEI has been random, fragmentary, infrequent, and insufficient. It has been frustrating to the point of lunacy. I cannot but conclude that IBEI is utterly unprepared, and unequipped, to participate as a member of the Mundus MAPP (or any other Erasmus Mundus) consortium.
column101: Alert the administration at the coordinating university (CEU)
column103: In the case of CEU, ABSOLUTELY. They have been extraordinarily responsive to student needs and concerns and more than willing to act positively on that feedback. In the case of my second year institution (IBEI), mixed bag. As previously mentioned, IBEI has been so catastrophic in terms of communication with students that it's hard to say anything has been done well. That being said, small day-to-day matters at the institute have, so far, been handled promptly and professionally. Which makes it even more of a shame that the big stuff ("when do classes start," "when do we need to arrive in Barcelona," "how does immigration work") have been such abject failures.
column117: IMMIGRATION COHESION. I know this is a complex issue involving the EU, individual nations, competencies, national and international law, and a host of other issues. But, as a non-EU student, nothing else has been as challenging and alarming as the experience of navigating the immigration procedures between the first and second year countries. It is beyond frustrating that I am here, accepted by schools in both countries, confirmed by the Commission, and even awarded an EU scholarship, only to have barrier after barrier thrown in my path by murky immigration processes that seem designed to make me throw my hands up in frustration and just quit. And indeed, in my Mundus MAPP program alone this year, one student was forced to quit the program after completing a year of work because his visa in his second-year country was denied, and at least one other was forced to leave her second-year country and fly back home indefinitely to complete a visa procedure that she was explicitly told she didn't need to bother with in the first place.
column118: Immigration, consortium cohesion, clarity from second-year school (IBEI)
column119: I want to give a special moment of praise here to my first-year school, CEU, which also coordinates the Mundus MAPP program. They have been nothing but exceptional from top to bottom. Responsive, clear, communicative (almost to a fault sometimes - we actually complained about getting too MANY e-mails!), friendly, welcoming, well-prepared, smooth, and functional. Just outstanding.

column118: -Thesis consultation. I was extremely dissatisfied with the follow up from Deusto during writing my thesis. As I was writing my thesis outside of Spain I could only contact my uni via email. They replied late and my supervisor hardly contacted me, not untill 2 weeks before the deadline of my thesis. Logically I seeked help other places than my uni. -administrative support at Deusto. They have an oldfashioned admin system that seriously needs to be imprived. Also, information on offers on stipends should reach the students before 3 days before the deadline -activities outside of school @Deusto
column119: Groningen has a great feedback program, and I also appreciated a lot the support from lecturers on academic matters. Also, coordinator did a great job.

column7: NOHA Mundus - Joint Master's Degree Program in International Humanitarian Action
column88: At University # 1 it took a while to get registered as a University Student, this has consequences when being a grantee student since it complicates the banking and scholarship process.  Some fellow students enrolled in other universities already had their student cards before arriving to the University.  In both Universities, there is an administrative conflict. When you are an international student enrolled in an Erasmus Mundus Master Course, it is difficult to know who can help you since the administrative department sometimes does not even know about this student status. Normally you have to ask the Master course responsible to help you through the enrollment process and many other administrative processes.  At University # 2, every single administrative step takes a lot of time. Even the master diploma has not been delivered after a year form graduation.

column88: In  Groningen there was half a day of introduction, but solely for our class. column103: In Groningen they seemed to make some changes every year, but in general the course (both in Groningen AND in Dublin) was so bad, so terribly unorganized and chaotic that they probably did not even remember or have the comments from the previous years. column104: DO SOMETHING WITH THE FEEDBACK YOU ARE BEING GIVEN! This program has SUCH a good potential but is not only making students dissatisfied, and this way no one will ever recommend it to other prospective students.

column7: NOHA Mundus - Joint Master's Degree Program in International Humanitarian Action
column88: Accommodation in my 1st university was cancelled 1 month previous to arrival due to me having a accompanying spouse. Although I had already informed the student housing staff about my spouse 3 months prior to arrival, they have confirmed accommodation at first and at last minute they cancelled it, what forced me to look for accommodation by myself, in a country in which I did not speak the language. After arrival, it took me more than 1 month to find accommodation for me and my spouse. This for sure compromised the quality of my academic participation during the first month of classes.
column101: At the time I was studying, I believe this matter should be first addressed to the host university. I believe only at a later point it should be forwarded to the coordinator university.
column103: My first university certainly addressed most of the issues reported by students and I was able to see it at my third semester, when I went back to the host university. Regarding my second university, I am not sure whether or not all issues reported have been addressed.
column104: In courses in which there are many professors per module, it would be important to evaluate each professor at the end of his/her classes already, not only at the end of the semester, when it is almost impossible to remember all issues to be reported regarding each of the professors. Another important point is to ask for the final/general feedback before the final exams, when students still feel attached to the course. After the final exams, master's students tend to forget or simply do not to care about issues to be improved.
column118: The universities were not necessarily smoothly integrated. The grading system and methods were different; similar academic modules were not properly integrated (i.e. the content of the international law module in the first university was broader and deeper than the one of the same module in my second university).
column119: Since my masters was very much profession-oriented, I believe it should have a more consisted field experience for all students. I am aware of some universities offering field experience opportunities, but this was not explained to all students, nor all of us were able to attend it - it was exclusively to the students that were at that specific university in that specific semester. A field experience should be systematically offered by all NOHA universities, so that all NOHA students are able to attend it.

column88: Much better coordination within and between faculty and universities in the network.  The programme was advertised as a joint degree programme but at the end  NONE of us received a joint degree and the asner from different faculties. Also, the level of the courses in Spain was much lowee than expected in many cases and the coordination of the faculty for clases was inexistant. Regarding Groningen I felt discriminated when grading MAY TOO MANY TIMES.
column118: 1) Discrimination of any kind, should not be accepted. a) There should be more visible and affective channels so students can report when they feel discrimination. b) That channel should make students feel confortable when expresing such a concern.  2) Many students consider a plus to have a joint degree. Then we should get a Joint degree at the end. The network should not promote a Joint programme if  it is not ready to provide a joint diploma.  3) Desuto can definitely improve, level of the content of the courses, coorindation and organization. It is the only University of the programme with no real fieldwork in the second semester. Spain has veru interesting experiences with ETA and with the the Francoism regarding Historic memory so is not like the University has to organise a trip to other countries (as other universities do) to do fieldwork.
column119: The programme is not worth the price payed. At some point my class even asked the Master Coordinator for an explanation on what was the money invested in, with no clear answer.

column103: The students were asked to work on a project of the year (a freely chosen 1-year project on which students should work on their business ideas and develop ideas to crate companies.  We were all really upset when we learnt that no money has been allocated to support these student projects to support prototype development, market research, tests etc. Instead the money is spent on maniford trip in which 100 students fly to another country and listen to presentations etc.  The students in our programme all agreed that this is also important to foster mobility amongst the students and get to know Europe. But we were suggesting to reduce the number of trips and use this money to support student's business ideas.  Furthermore we had other minor issues we addresses through the representative but nothing was changed - no follow up was provided etc.
column104: - there should always be a student representative during consortium meetings who tries to find out aforehand what students see as improvements and brings their opinion forward during these meetings.
column118: 1.) In my programme the overall coordinator has changed during the 2-year programme. In my opinion, I think that the people currently in charge of my programme who organise and lead it are not aware/cannot live/cannot transmit the vision of Erasmus Mundus Master Courses. This leads to unclarities, lack of motivation of the students (e.g. no prober feedback is given etc.), dissatisfaction with the programme. This is in my opinion a big problem for SELECT in future, since I will not be able to fully recommend the programme. I highly appreciate the idea of Erasmus Mundus and SELECT but I do not believe that the current coordinators will be able to carry through this vision and be an inspiring person to both students and the other people involved in the programme.  2.)I think the money allocation should be truely revised. The students are in general highly motivated individuals - who WANT TO WORK HARD and CHANGE something in Europe/in the world. Many want to become entrepreneurs and contribute positively to the society they live in. Therefore, in my opinion the money should be addressed to that mainly: money for funding student projects, community projects etc. should be available and the money spent on travels, seminars etc. should be reduces to an appropriate number - these 'gatherings' should be organised in more digital manners (distant workshops etc.)  3.) A stonger focus should lie on the time after the programme. Europe is aiming at bringing top-most international students to work in Europe, create companies and improve the situation. Now however, after finishing the programme many especially international students are stuggeling to find a job and often have to back to their countries, risking never to be able to come back. Here lies a big problem in my opinion, that the programme has: there is almost no support available to offer these people opportunieties, support them in truely learning languages (which is the key to finding a job in another country).  I would suggest to either increase the potential to get in contact with industrial partners during the programme or offer the students INTENSIVE language course (time should be allocated for that) either during the programme.
column119: I highly appriciate the opportunity to provide my feedback to 'higher' levels in the Erasmus Mundus hierachy, if possible this could also be done after the first year on a more direct path in order to create the pressure for programme coordinators to ensure that they take on the student's feedback and improve the programme at a faster pace.

column118: 1. Student life is masters level is of a much higher stature. It would have been great if I had opportunities for Research/Teachning Assistantships during my studies that could complement my career as well as education. Universities and professors must make a way for that and utilize this easily available talent. 2.There is a huge difference in the fees between Category A and B, where individually these universities charge very less amount of fees. If this was purely business, then it wouldn't have been of concern. But business, as I understand, if of last concern to the European Commission facilitating these courses. Additionally, those from Cat B are normally from underdeveloped countries and struggle a lot to find the means.  3. Course content is like all conventional teaching techniques with little of no importance to contemporary industrial world. Hands-on experience facilitated by the program in a live industrial environment would be an added advantage. In fact, classroom theory learning is not the game anymore. Actually I was expecting something like this and was disappointed to a great extend. (I am not taking about laboratory practicals which has nothing to do with live experience)
column119: I am an Indian student in the SpaceMaster programme. I have done my first year and is currently in the second year. Now, I was expecting of working in the industry atleast with an internship after graduation. But to my great disappointment, everywhere I knock, I am (we) getting a response saying that they are preferring European students/nationals. We are paying huge amounts since in category B, but still, it is much harder for us to find a spot in the industry where we can put our knowledge to use. I would suggest the consortium organizing the internship modules/training sessions integrated along with the program content since that wont be a problem in that level of delegation. If that is highly impossible, I would suggest that the consortium arrange a campus-selection drive in the universities participating in the program to select students based on their performance in academics and interviews right from the campus (employers coming to campus for hiring interns).

About international experience, I was surprised that first 5 months I had troubles to understand other students, not because of the language, but because different cultural background. Afterwards, it has been much more easier. In total I am really happy that I was a part of this Erasmus Mundus Program.

column118: only one aspect, it is about a time for work and other exercises that a student should do alone. this time should be  adequate. For me it looks like people from Uni Würzurg do not have an idea how much time in reality their exercises are needed.
column119: I think it would be good if a document with a schedule would be available. I mean that this doc should include information about how many exercises this course has, how much time teachers expect from me to spend on these exercises. So from this doc I can understand how much time I should spend in total every week for all activities(including lectures, seminars and etc), and if it is more than 40 hours per week I can understand that something wrong.

column117: Maintaining and improving academic quality of the programmes
column118: Academic level and expectations to the students - the courses could be more difficult and challenging.   Language courses - no intensive language courses were offered during our round of the program which is really a shame since this is one of the great advantages of studying abroad.  Much better bureaucratic cooperation between the consortium universities - for example exchange of student data, grades etc.
column119: Personally I am a EU citizen, but I really fell that Visa regulations (and mostly just poor and slow case-handling) for my non-EU colleagues significantly restricted their options - for example getting a relevant summer internship, even if they already had found a company willing to hire them. Or the fact that they have to apply for Visa for each new semester, if they choose a new consortium university. I believe, once a non-EU students is enrolled in a two-year EU program, he/she should have the freedom to move around Europe during those two years - without having to wait months after months on Visa handling every half year and pay significant Visa application fees.

column7: STeDe - Erasmus Mundus Master in Sustainable Territorial Development
column101: via e-mail to all the Academic Directors from the universities in the consortium
column118: 1. Moving phase from one place to another: usually it was very stressful since accomodation was not provided.  2. More time to work on a master thesis: last semester was devoted to internship and thesis and there was not enough time plus the choice of the thesis topic was done too late (at the beggining of the last semester).  3. More structured courses: there were some overlaps of the courses between the universities.
column119: More free choice: as an European I was urged to go to Brazil for the last semester of my master. However, I was not willing to do so and it was not obligatory to go there. Nevertheless, the coordinator from Paris university kept insisting on me to go and other coordinators had no power over him to change this. Only due to health problems, I managed to stay in Europe and work with the professor I wanted to work. This is the most unpleasant experience from the whole master and I would like to make sure that the next batches will avoid this kind of situation.   Moreover, the same coordinator was giving very personal grades and the people that had different point of view, were usually awarded with the lower grade. Oftentimes, the academic skills and capacities had no importance in assessing people's academic performance.

column7: STeDe - Erasmus Mundus Master in Sustainable Territorial Development
column88: The "Kickoff" seminar was very long and it included a lot of material that was not relevant to the Sustainable Territorial Development MA program. We had an entire morning where the information that was presented applied only to a Master's program in Local Development and we were obligated to attend. Furthermore, some of the Faculty at the University of Padova namely the program administrator (Mr. Edgar Serrano) and Professor Anna Giraldo do NOT speak English, yet they are expected to teach or facilitate in English.
column101: I have no idea
column103: I was informed that in the past, when students have made recommendations, they have been adhered to
column104: I believe that all professors and staff should be evaluated by students, in addition to peer evaluations.
column118: We found this experience to be incredibly bureaucratic both in Italy and France. We had to apply for student visas and were responsable for our own housing at each place. This is incredibly time consuming and wasteful (considering that the EU has a system in place which ideally should facilitate movemnent amongst educational institutions). Additionally, we were quite disappointed in the quality of the professors at Padova University. Notably the Program Director Professor Faggi whose teaching methods are archaic and who is unable to listen to students' opinions. Also Professor Anna Giraldo is a mediocre profesional. She discouraged questions from students and when she was asked for things that she did not know, she would simply say ": I do not know, that is not relevant" . But in some cases the information was crucial.
column119: There should be a space for positive comments as well. Professor Alessio Surian is excellent and Professor Claudia Padovani is good. They deserve recognition, especially when taking into consideration that other professionals do not uphold they same excellent academic standards that they do. Finally, we have Heard rumors about  the program director from Paris  Leo Dayan(Sorbonne Panteón I)  who has given an unfair advantage to certain students (his son's best friend and a personal friend of his) when it came to obtaining scholarships. This is unacceptable

One meets people from all over the world (people that are studying what you're studying and thus with which one most of the time shares also other interests) and this enhances and widens also your general culture.

column104: STUDENTS SHOULD BE AWARE, THAT THOSE FEEDBACKS AFTERWARDS WILL HELP TO IMPROVE THINGS.
column118: 1.EVALUATIONS: Taking exams after 8hour lectures is NOT a good way to mark students. With this you only make students stressed. 2.RESPONSIBLE: There were professors to hear alumni complaints, but actually they were not changing anything.  3.ORGANISATION: They do not have a clue of how much homework they are sending. (In my case I was staying awake until 3.00am several days trying to finish the stuff).
column119: -They have to put a person who is in CHARGE of controlling how much work they are sending, as well as checking the examinations.  -I did learn a lot in this master. However, what is the price to pay? How many hours should I spend doing homework? If they really think that all that stuff should be done, then they should start earlier giving lectures. -In the first year alumni was sharing a room during the intensive course, that is not so bad. Nevertheless, I was sharing the BED for a week with another student in another intensive course, that' horrible!

column117: Bringing all students and alumni of the course together to resolve problems. Also evaluation system varies from university to the university (e.g. it's well known that grades in Italy are "easier" than in Netherlands) - this should be standardized for whole course.
column118: Have better introduction about research possibilities at each university and groups working there (quite often the web-page of the group is inadequate and updates once in a century). Also I would appreciate meeting rest of the people from my master earlier (I used to be the only student of my programme in my home-university, so I met the rest of the people from the EM master just after first year, which is a pity, since they're great people).

column7: TEOS - Transcultural European Outdoor Studies
column88: I question why Univ of Cumbria is hosting the program at a satellite campus that is largely under construction and inaccessible. Many student services and resources that I would expect are not available and this is significantly impacting the academic and wellness of my experience.
column101: Unclear for the entire consortium unless through a coordinator. Feedback discussions have been held regarding courses and overall experience, but likely as a result of student discontent in the first course.
column103: Feedback was just recently given.
column104: Clearly designate a representative at each school and explain this during orientation sessions.
column118: 1. Academic structure and content at Uni Cumbria - only 1 course as of yet, but I would fail all the course outcomes after completing the in class time. 2. Transparency and assistance in finding accommodation. TEOS should have options and keeping the full together should be a priority clearly explained and presented. 3. As part of orientation there should be some general living excursions to a nearby city. Although public transit is important I would expect the school, not just the coordinator, to welcome such a diverse program. At this point I feel the school only sees us a money sources. A visit to the USA and exploration of student affairs would be of high value.
column119: Although only 2 months in, apart from the exceptional student composition, I am not inclined to recommend this program to my fellow nationals. The introduction has not been strong or organized enough to create meaningful experiences or education.  I am also discouraged regarding the organization of finances. I would have expected that my scholarship would commence shortly after arrival not 1-2 months into my stay. I have had to extend a significant amount of credit to finance my first few months despite sending in my bank information months in advance. The organization is poor, and I was not warned that I should have upwards of $5000 USD in reserve should the programme be exceptionally slow.

column7: TEOS - Transcultural European Outdoor Studies
column101: Contact professor at current university
column103: I spend just two months of this programme so I'm not sure about whole programme. But now I face many problems due to bad system of current university and the lack of communication between each universities.
column118: The support for international students from the university and consortium coordinator (They don't help about visa issues, bank etc. students have to search information, apply, appoint date for submit documents and do it all by themselves)
column119: I met the problem since before the semester started. I received the application letter form  and was informed to wait for student agreement and further information but the consortium coordinator didn't give where and how I could contact with him. After a week passed I sent an e-mail to him but there is no respond. Then I sent e-mails to the Universities (both university that would the first semester start and the university coordinator) but I've never gotten the reply. A month passed I sent e-mail to the coordinator again and this time he replied that he sent me e-mails and I didn't reply him, thus, he cancelled the scholarship for me. I claimed that I've never gotten further e-mail from him except the letter of acceptance. Then he asked the EU commission to move me back to reserved list. I had to wait if anyone cancelled the offer, I would got the scholarship again. In mid August, I got the e-mail and call from him informing that I got the scholarship. I had to apply for visa in short duration and missed the first week of the semester. When I talked with TEOS students, many told me that they met the problems about wrong spelling in their significant documents from the coordinator. I heard that the coordinator had to do everything by himself (without assistant). That's why he was so busy (sometimes he didn't reply e-mails).

column118: The university facilities. At the moment, University of Cumbria is under construction because of what I believe, a bankruptcy. Most of the campus area is a building site. I do not know what the campus was like before they started building, but at the moment there are no social spaces for students, there are no gym facilities, there is no cafe, there is no room that is reserved for studying or reading. In the library there are very few places to sit, there are not really any library staff, and all in all I am not sure what I am paying for. The lectures are ok, but I am also paying for attending a university, a social and academic space which I do not think is in place. I think that  a) the university should have created more temporary spaces than they have for the students or  b) should have given the student a compensation for the conditions in terms of lower fees.

column118: 1. Degree issuance 2. Internship assistance 3. Class content
column119: 1. It took two years to get a degree from KTH, the first university we attended because: A. They were not happy with the transcripts Duke University (second university) sent. It happened Duke sent an electronic copy, they said after two months it was not good, so Duke printed them out and mailed them. After several months KTH said OK to the SAME thing. B. They claimed to be on vacation God knows how many months. C. They blamed it on administrative staff not doing their work. I don't know if I can manage to convey how frustrating it's been for the 4 students of us who went to Duke as mobility option. Some people risked to have their US work visa or they employment offers not confirmed because they could not show a degree. etc.  2. No assistance whatsoever in finding internships in industry. Most of the companies they managed to set agreements with were German and would not hire any non-German speaking person. I also heard non euroepan people had troubles because none of the companies would hire them as foreigners. Many companied who claimed to be programme partners and had their logo all over the place in the masters did not offer a SINGLE internship, Very misleading and almost a fraud.

column117: General issues about the quality of the course if a significant number of students has a similar problem
column118: 1) Due to the very tight schedule, there was partly no time to enjoy the fact of being in three different places. At some point, we barely had time to sleep, but on the other hand, the 3-months summer break was far too long. For sure it is a difficult task to change the time frame of each semester since it is dependent on the system of each country, but if it was possible, it would have been better to have slightly less of a summer semester break for the sake of a more relaxed schedule. 2) The teaching standards in Le Creusot should be improved. The first problem was a weekly changing time table which made it hard to plan study times and organise the project work. Furthermore, there was very few input from the lab tutors to help us, I even once got the answer "if you want to know that, you have to teach yourself." I do not deny that Master studies should be self-organised in some extent, but for this big amount of topics to learn it is helpful to get a bit of advice from the tutors. 3) It would have been nice to get more opportunities to learn languages. Maybe it could be considered to let the students choose between the "Local Culture" course and a language course.
column119: In general, the VIBOT programme is really rich and gives a good overview about the whole field.  It would be nice though to introduce an international grading scheme since the non-linear grading system in France is not really comparable to the linear grading systems in Spain or the UK for example.

When the time arrived of choosing the project, they told us that the rules had changed and that we should stay only with the parter companies or universities of the consortium. Is not fare that when you apply and enter the master there are cetain rules and that during the course they just change this applying it with few flexibility. -In the case of Burgunfy Univeristy.- I think that they need to upgrade a little bit the quality of the course or professors. -In the case of Girona.- Give quicker feedback, most labas and works were graded till the end of the course, in some cases with no clear rules of evaluation.  -In HW scotland.- We dont have a secretary like in France or Girona that can help us with general issues, it will be nice to have one. column118: - I consider that the course is not that well structured. First, it is a course in vision and robotics but most of the courses are related to vision. To give a puntual example, no course about kinematics was taught. Moreover, I found out that during the first year, a lot of content is repeated, especially regarding image processing and medical imaging, and that this content is not the state-of-the-art. In the third semester we start to learn about advanced stuff.  - In my opinion, the third semester is one of the most important and yet the shortest one.  - There are many assignments, projects and exams and limited time. I agree that one learns by doing and I like that way of learning but when the time is not enough I feel that I am expected to do it more or less without going any deeper. However, then the grades reflect that I did not go any deeper.
column119: I think that a lot of students, including myself, disagreed with respect to the grades scale conversion. Maybe it is because it was not clearly explained in the student agreement we signed or because we do not understand the french grading system. Particularly, I felt like I did a better second semester but this was not well reflected by the conversion to the french system which is the official since the University in France is the coordinator University.

column88: The experience I've made in both the universities has been unique in terms of competences development and professional growth. To be clearer, I had the opportunity to improve (obviously) my knowledge about work, organizational and personnel psychology but the most important role was played by the context in which I built new professional relationship with students from all over Europe. In particular the collaboration between teams and the exchange of the cultural knowledge with all the european students have improved my skills and abilities to work in different contexts and to hold the best characteristics from them.

column88: At the university of Coimbra we could have started by receiving the correct address and locations of where to do the first administrative and enrollment procedures.  Also where to find things in the city (eg accommodation, bank, hospital, etc.). Information on local transportation, map of the university, important phone numbers (like of the places we had to contact and go to).  Introduce the Faculty, information about resources such as library, etc.  I wish there was an on boarding handbook with basic information.
column101: We would send an email to our university coordinator or the Consortium coordinator. However there is no open door policy. Me and the ones who tried to give feedback during the course faced a lot of resistant from the coordinators and some of us felt harmed.
column103: Simple suggestions that we would make along the semester would not be taken into consideration. We would get a message that things were the way they were and we would have to adapt.
column104: It should start with the coordinators' attitude. They should welcome suggestions, be humble and open. Treat us as professional and adults with strong background, not as children being taught how to behave.  Secondly there could be a formal channel. I've had very specific, measurable and present feedback that I could never share. I tried to contact the European Union commission with an email address shared in a letter I received, saying they would welcome feedback. But never got a reply.
column118: Administration support & Organisation: incl. visa, banking and enrollment processes, accommodation, public/city and university info, etc; send schedules in advance, have processes such as the ones mentioned before documented and available; consistency of information.  Instructors quality: experienced professors to teach, not substitutes; provide lectures and share their knowledge, not only student presentations for all semester; know English; provide high quality level of resources/ materials for study.  Work life balance: prioritise quality and not quantity; enable student engagement with other collaborative initiatives such as allowing students to enroll in other universities of the consortium; allow and encourage students opportunities of practice for big multinationals (this is good for master reputation and for student) Have a feedback channel to adjust things as they come by.

column7: IMEC - International Master in Early Childhood Education and Care
column88: In Malta, I felt that we did not have any kind of support. We were introduced on the first day about the faculty structure and so on, but we did not have any conversation with the domestic students, and we did not see our proposed administrator any more throughout all the semester.
column101: We should firstly write the matter to the coordinator at the current university, and afterwards she would organize the consortium meeting and give us their opinions, decisions and the like. We have never met with all members of the consortium at the same time to talk.
column103: In some cases they had improved many things, but there were things that have never been improved.
column104: I think that it is important to have a meeting with all consortium members where we can discuss together, students and the consortium.
column117: I think the course representative should address the issues regarding the thesis time, since it appeared as the biggest issue of our course so far.
column118: - the universities had completely different standards, and consequently this caused a great difference during the time of writing thesis - I sometimes was wondering how some people were selected for the programme, since they didn't show any interest or involvement during lectures, discussions and the like. - I think that the fact that we didn't have grades but just comments for our tasks and final papers is a big issue. You can work hard and be active and in the end only the mark of your thesis is the fact that shows what you have been doing for two years. This enabled some students to do nothing. However, in the end it turned that your thesis is evaluated by examiners who do not know anything about your progress throughout the studies. This just supports the idea that you can do nothing in regards to modules, but if you finish your thesis in the "right" (I mean right in accordance to your examiners' opinion) you can finish the programme with the best mark as the ones who worked hard all the time. This is so unfair system of grading.
column119: I think that the grading system throughout the course was completely unfair. As we had just comments, so it enabled some people to work almost nothing. Conversely, in the end of the studies the people who did nothing are able to get A or B, as the ones who worked hard all the time. Furthermore, this is such a big issue, since if you want to apply for any PhD you need to show your performance, progress and the grades. What can we show if we had this way of grading?

column117: Scholarships- the division between EU and Non-EU should not exist when we are all living in the same country with the same bills etc to pay.  I understand extra support for visa applications and flights but for some Non- EU people these costs were not so high when their home country was close enough to one of the countries we would study in
column118: 1. Scholarship 2. Be given the chance to meet other      students within the Universities 3. More organisation from the course as a               whole
column119: 1. Scholarship- as expressed previously we all have the same things to pay for when we are living in the countries we are studying in. As an EU student it was not possible for me to apply for any additional grant from my home country.  As you are probably aware the cost of living in Norway and Dublin is quite high when you have to take accommodation, transport and food into consideration. Other students who had the bigger scholarship were able to go travelling during our holidays over the two years whilst some students on the smaller grant struggled with day-day basic living.  This was unfair. To further the problem with the scholarship was delayed payments and also payments with an incorrect amount (less than what I should have got). In my case this took a few payments before it was sorted properly and then resulted in uneven payments for a few months. The scholarship was something which should have occurred every month at the same time with no problems since we were getting the same amount each month.  3. Overall, there were organisational issues within the course which again should be known and sorted beforehand. I do take into consideration the course is only new so there would things that are not 100% sorted.  With regard to the thesis, the thesis course handbook needs to be more detailed and concise especially in terms of the marking criteria which still remains unclear to me. I consulted APA, the thesis handbook and the University handbook where I completed my thesis. In some cases, there were conflicting requirements. The thesis handbook should be elaborated further to come to one common core thesis requirements or else allowing for students to individualise their own thesis.

column119: Why is it that in Malta the visas were free and in Ireland we have to pay 500 euros in visa fees? 150 euros for entry, 300 for residence permit and 100 euros for multiple entry visa. Also, in Malta, residence permits get processed for months upon application.

column7: IMEC - International Master in Early Childhood Education and Care
column101: Speak to class rep who would contact course co-ordinator who would pass on the matter or arrange meeting.
column118: Increased financial support for european students so that there is parity between EU and nonEU students

column7: IMEC - International Master in Early Childhood Education and Care
column101: Either, have the class represntative bring the matter up with the course administrator, or do it themselves. The course administrator would then bring it up with the consortium.
column103: I feel that the consortium has improved on what was lacking as much as they could although I would have liked to be notified of those improvements so I would know that I was listened to.
column104: Perhaps it would be possible to make the recommendations from the students availble for all students to see/read, and for the answers from the consortium also to be public. It is important for us student to be feel that they are listening to us, even if they may not be able to implement all the changes we wanted.
column117: Academic quality.
column118: Financial support for EU student Student housing Change the grading system, I would like to get grades for each module instead of Passed/Failed.
